-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: Team Doodly wants to better serve you in 2020. Here's how.
Date: Thu, 02 Jan 2020 11:42:46 -0600
From: Brad Callen <doodly@bryxen.com>
To: Todd McCaffrey <todd@toddwriter.com>

Preview

Hey Todd, 2019 has been a great year for the Doodly community. We've 
interacted with so many incredible Doodlers (mainly via the private 
Facebook group 
<https://bryxen.acemlna.com/lt.php?s=e6528b5af8d60160647c91e234f808d0&i=206A249A7A744>) 
and we've seen so many absolutely amazing Doodle videos that have been 
created in the past year, alone.

Going into 2020, we want to continue supporting you as best we can. In 
order to do that, we have 2 super short questions to ask you.

Would you mind taking 10 seconds of your time and letting us know the 
answers to these 2 questions?

Go here to see the 2 questions:

https://forms.gle/jAQx81NC8EK5z3zeA 
<https://bryxen.acemlna.com/lt.php?s=e6528b5af8d60160647c91e234f808d0&i=206A249A7A745>

Thank you so much for helping make Doodly what it is today, and here's 
to a fantastic 2020!

Brad Callen

Sent to: todd@toddwriter.com

Unsubscribe 
<http://bryxen.acemlna.com/proc.php?nl=7&c=206&m=249&s=e6528b5af8d60160647c91e234f808d0&act=unsub> 

Bryxen Inc, 6724 Perimeter Loop Road #257, Dublin , OH 43017, United States

To: Jay A. Katz <Jkatz@mdmc-law.com>, Diana Tyler <Diana@mbalit.co.uk>, Gigi <gigi@pernhome.com>
Subject: Fwd: Weyr Search e-copy?

FYI

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: Weyr Search e-copy?
Date: Tue, 7 Jan 2020 16:46:19 -0500
From: Trevor Quachri <tquachri@dellmagazines.net>
To: todd@toddwriter.com
CC: Emily Hockaday <ehockaday@dellmagazines.net>

Hi Todd,

As part of ANALOG’s 90th anniversary year in 2020, we’re breaking our 
“no reprints” rule and running retrospectives on a handful of stories 
that someone close to the magazine feels a particularly strong personal 
connection to. Emily Hockaday, our Managing Editor (who has been with us 
nearly a decade), picked “Weyr Search,” for its formative effect on her 
as a young reader. I’m writing 1) just to give you a friendly heads-up; 
I’ve already reached out to Vaughne Hansen at Virginia Kidd with the 
paperwork, and 2) to ask if you might have an electronic version of the 
story you’d be able to provide us?

Best,
Trevor

Trevor Quachri
Editor,
ANALOG SCIENCE FICTION AND FACT

Write an email in my voice.
To: Kelly Lockhart <kellylockharttn@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: WE SHALL RISE anthology invite

On 2/8/2020 11:02, Kelly Lockhart
 wrote:

So... what do you think? 

I had to take a break for a bit and get in some light reading --
 Rick Atkinson's
 
Pulitzer Prize-winning 
An Army at Dawn

 and 
Day of Battle
.

I finished book 4 at 5 a.m. this morning.  I went back and
 re-read the last chapter at least twice just because I'm a sucker
 for such lines as:

“Combat Ops, Combat Ops, Navy One. Say again
 . . . Navy 
One
 .
 . .
 Over.”

Is there a Bible available?

I see that there are books 5,6, and 7
 although they seem to be anthologies, am I right?

And do we have a future timeline?

I was sad to see that the ISS was used up...
 that had been my first story idea.

Also, I thinking about the nature of the
 H7D3 infection, it would seem to me that one solution to the
 infected would be take advantage of their changed physiology --
 they're not quite 
homo sapiens sapiens
 anymore, they're
 a separate species.  In fact, unless John is planning on having
 baby zombies, they're genetically a sport (can't reproduce) -- a
 dead end.

I'm dubious about the current populations of
 infected still alive.  A human without clothing is a very naked
 ape.  A human eating only flesh will find all sorts of vitamin
 deficiencies -- scurvy and rickets are high on the list.  Add to
 that the return of lice (always a source of protein) and other
 parasites and I don't see the infecteds being very long-lived.

So, if formication is the start of the final
 infectious phase, presumably leading to brain swelling and
 necrosis of large amounts of the cerebral hemisphere, it might
 make sense to 
finish the job
 by releasing a virus that
 pushes the infected over the edge.

A simple method would be infected food --
 "poisoned" with something contagious and terminal.  That would
 leave all those rotting bodies however (that seems to be a given
 in any situation).

One possibility would be arranging a "trap"
 that included thistles (they itch like crazy) and let the
 infected itch themselves to a final death (nasty, I know).

Another possibility might be some sort of
 virus that attacks along the same pathways as the original H7D3
 but inactivates the infected's mitochrondria (the powerhouse of
 the cells) and let them die of lethargy (perhaps a bit more
 humane).  Make it infectious and the only problem is ensuring
 that regular humans (particularly those still lost) can't catch
 it.

Another possibility is to arrange a virus
 that makes the infected light phobic.  They won't come out at
 night and are afraid of bright lights.  Make them underground
 vampires.  I suppose adding excessive sound sensitivity to their
 ills might also reduce their population.  How about simply
 figuring out a way to make them afraid of regular humans?  And
 while we're at it, why can't we just engineer a virus that makes
 them hate the smell of normal humans?  Make it so that they stay
 away from 
homo sapiens sapiens
 and just let them die out
 in peace.  (I know this kinda walks around all the loud
 explosions and raining body parts but it makes more sense).

It would seem to me that, at the very least,
 arranging physical contact with the survivors in the CDC --
 presumably the largest concentration of biological knowledge
 left in the world, would be a high priority.

It would also seem to me that if I'm going
 to contribute, I'd best understand the other contributions
 already made -- no point in writing 10,000 words only to
 discover that that particular story has already been told.

From a recovery point of view, one of the
 first problems is going to be food.  Planting, harvesting,
 distributing something easy.  Probably any agriculture will
 include potatoes (easy to plant, maintain, dig up -- not a great
 source of protein).  I think you might also want to consider
 some varieties of "super-food" (like genetically enhanced
 potatoes that include more vitamins).

The other problem, after food, will be
 shelter, clothing, medicine, metal-working.  And maybe there
 should be some thought given to better methods of construction,
 production, etc.  This world has a humungous manpower problem
 which means that individuals will be able to charge very highly
 for their time, effort, and skills (like after the Black
 Death).  Rebuilding chains of production may be easier,
 particularly if there are some advanced production lines mostly
 intact.  Labor saving devices will be even more than a must than
 they were after the Black Death, so innovation will be highly
 prized (and paid).  I'd expect to see robots everything (ain't
 nothing stopping some reverse engineering using simple motors
 and ancient computers).

-- Todd

kellylockharttn@gmail.com

 was. 
 

Gotta love computers...

Write an email in my voice.
To: Kelly Lockhart <kellylockharttn@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: WE SHALL RISE anthology invite

On 2/15/2020 05:16, Kelly Lockhart
 wrote:

Yes, there is a bible, which I have attached. And
 there are two more novels that cover Tom Smith's story (Steve's
 brother, who worked for the bank), but those are parallel to the
 main storyline. Chuck Gannon has a new novel coming out, which I
 just got in this week and haven't had a chance to read yet. 
 

And yes, there are two anthologies, which I have also
 attached. Sarah Hoyt is also working on a full novel, and
 Ringo has been plotting out the next "main" novel. It's a busy
 and nicely profitably universe (both anthologies continue to
 pay royalties and were published in hardcover, the last one
 debuting at #1 on the bookscan SF/F chart). 
 

As to your other questions... yes, there population of
 infected has been substantially reduced by the time of the
 new anthology (basically set in the first spring/summer
 after the Fall). However, even a "base brain" homo sapiens
 is a remarkably resilient creature. That said, this
 anthology is basically moving past the "zombie menace".

Ringo wrote a bit from the first State of the Union
 speech after the U.S. government has (sort of) reformed to
 use as the thematic base for the anthology: “Though we have
 much to do, the great threat has ended. The infected are but
 a background nuisance. The question becomes, where do we go
 from here? This I will tell you as your President. We shall
 not fall. We shall not enter ‘a thousand year night.’ We
 will triumph over this adversity as America has always
 triumphed. The Fall is ended. We shall Rise.”

 The “centerpiece story” of the next main line Smith book
 will be about saving the infrastructure, primarily in the
 Eastern United States. Dams, locks, bridges. That is the
 primary focus for the ‘Feds’. What’s everyone else doing
 wherever they are in the world is the focus on this
 anthology. 

Well, I'm adaptable.

But I gotta say... if you're rebuilding a country, don't start
 with outdated systems.  Dams, locks, bridges... why?

Dams I can see for flood prevention and energy generation but I
 don't see why the ideal should be re-inventing what existed before
 -- the trick is to step BEYOND that.  Again, the lack of
 population is going to demand labor-saving at all levels,
 particularly in agriculture (farming).  You aren't going back to
 the old ways, they won't work (they require a much larger
 population).  You've got to think smart, and different.

Solar and wind power are available (and the Dutch have been using
 windmills for centuries).

Why rebuild a road infrastructure?  Why not revitalize rails? 
 Why not automate rail transport, using roll-on-roll-off containers
 and automated movement systems?  And, for that matter, how much
 cargo is there to move?

The biggest issue is population sustenance and growth.  The US
 build up so well because there was a flood of immigration.  This
 time would be very different.

Is there conversation group for this?  One of my pet peeves is
 the desire to build a self-managed medical system.  You've a
 dearth of doctors, instead of following the old Johns Hopkins
 hyper-perfectionist model why not develop home-use systems that
 allow people to mostly tend to themselves?

In terms of agriculture, I'm thinking that highly-mechanized,
 localized systems are possibly best (I can it "a farm in a box"),
 something that's tightly integrated to the city, part of the city,
 so that there is no "rural vs. urban" issue anymore (you'd need
 it, you just don't have the manpower).

What is the thinking on global warming? Clearly with the
 population so based there isn't any major contributions towards
 the problem but the problem still exists and it will take time to
 reverse (unless you posit that runaway global warming has already
 started).  So you've got rising sea levels, so building right next
 to the shore is not a good idea.  You've got weather issues, too.

One thing you're going to want to get back quickly is a space
 industry, including launch capabilities (what happened in French
 Guyana?  Did SpaceX do a "soft landing"? (I'd think so, Musk is a
 smart guy)).

My opinion is that the older, less nimble corporations didn't
 anticipate the level of destruction leveled by the virus.  The
 younger, more nimble corporations were better suited to handling
 the disaster.  What about Virgin Galactic?  That might have
 survived (but who needs sub-orbital capabilities?).

If the question really is -- what next? Then let's talk.  What
 are the goals of the survivors of the US?  The same ol' same old? 
 Or something better?

What's the status of fusion?  I know there's at least one group
 in Canada thinking they've got a good shot now.  What if they
 succeeded and enough of them survived (in the cold)?

How hard is it to get a chip fabrication plant back online, given
 power?

What about the CDC?  If the crisis of the infected is mostly
 over, is Atlanta (mostly) habitable?  Are cities mostly wasted and
 useless (build new "cities")?

How much do you want me to lead and how much do you want me to
 follow?

You're going to want to get the internet back up, at least at the
 Wi-Fi and major datacenter levels.  Who re-starts Amazon? (Because
 there's a lot of stuff there and a good logistics system).

-- Todd

On Sat, Feb 15, 2020 at 1:04
 AM todd <
todd@toddwriter.com

Write an email in my voice.
To: Kelly Lockhart <kellylockharttn@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: WE SHALL RISE anthology invite

On 2/22/2020 07:40, Kelly Lockhart
 wrote:

I'll pass along you author suggestions to John and
 see what he thinks.
 

Well, here's what I've got:

“Forward, Not Back” -- that’s my motto for what comes next.

My story is about starting up the internet, getting an Amazon.com warehouse on-line with electric delivery drones and starting to rebuild.  Longer term, the container Port of Los Angeles needs to be secured and container ships re-started and automated. Robots everywhere.

Attached are longer notes/ramblings.

If that works, then send me a contract.

-- Todd

As for the JPL folks, while the ones in LA would all but
 certainly have perished, remote places might well have made
 it. Could be an interesting story.

Also, does this mean I should send you a contract for the
 anthology? :-) 

-- Kelly

On Tue, Feb 18, 2020 at 6:43
 PM todd <
todd@toddwriter.com

On
 2/16/2020 03:47, Kelly Lockhart wrote:

 Hi Kelly,

 So my brain keeps wheeling around to the satellites.  There
 was talk of 

 someone still at Kwajalein? That makes sense.

 I also know people at JPL and I think they'd do SOMETHING to
 make sure 

 that their probes were still being monitored. (Maybe send a
 bunch of 

 prospects out to likely survival areas -- like Kwajalein)

 Also, are you looking for any more authors for this
 anthology?  If so, 

 I'd suggest Craig Martelle (ex-marine major, lawyer, author)
 and 

 Jonathee Brazee (ex-marine colonel) as likely prospects. 
 Craig was up 

 for a Dragon and I think Jonathan was a Neb nominee.  Just
 following the 

 ol' Army rule: "There ain't no dumb question 'cept the
 question not asked."

 -- Todd
You are Toddric, Todd’s helpful assistant with Todd’s tone.

 Weekly Horoscope: Sunday, February 23, 2020

 Pisces (Feb. 19-March 20)

Well, this continues to be an interesting time for you because you are 
empowered and energizes with the Sun in your sign! This is a good thing. 
It will attract people and favourable situations to you. (We like!) 
However, Mercury Retrograde is also in your sign! This is like a magnet 
for goofy situations. Misplaced items, forgotten appointments, delays, 
little frustrations, confused communications, and a general sense of 
feeling disorganized will create obstacles for you. Because Mars is in 
your House of Friendships, be careful you don't take your frustrations 
out on a friend. Chill out. Meanwhile, the good news is that Venus will 
attract money to you. It will also encourage you to buy beautiful things 
for yourself and loved ones. It might even attract new ways to earn 
money? Yes!

 Horoscopes by Holiday: Feb. 23, 2020 by Holiday Mathis

*PISCES* (Feb. 19-March 20). Time will reveal the difference between a 
beneficial and a detrimental distraction. What’s good for one era of 
life brings little benefit to another era. You’ll intuitively find the 
right thing to chase at the right time.

*TODAY’S BIRTHDAY* (Feb. 23). Funding comes for a project, and soon 
after you’ll enter a brief period of wonderful solo interior discovery. 
Your focus on unraveling a problem will end in an exciting breakthrough 
and fresh interest. Then you will love – go all-in. And then it’s 
springtime, your whole heart wide as fields, alive in flowers and 
buzzing bees. Scorpio and Leo adore you. Your lucky numbers are: 4, 48, 
22, 5 and 39.

*CELEBRITY PROFILES*: It has been announced that Dakota Fanning will 
star in “The Bell Jar,” an adaptation of the Sylvia Plath novel about a 
young woman struggling with mental illness. Fanning was born when the 
sun, Venus and Saturn were all in artistic and empathetic Pisces. Her 
natal moon is in Leo, the sign of entertainment, and her natal Mercury 
and Mars shine from intellectually and socially savvy Aquarius.

Happy birthday!

Love,

Dad

I’m so proud to be a part of this
 amazing collection, and I’m glad each and every one of you
 have been able to contribute your talent.

 

I hope you’re all safe and well,
 and I look forward to when I can send you a finished copy
 (and more great news).

 

Have a great weekend.

 

All the best,

 

David
 

 

 

Review Issue Date: 
May 15, 2020

Online Publish Date: 
May 4, 2020

Publisher:
 Harper Voyager

Pages: 
576

Price ( Hardcover ): 
$35.00

Publication Date: 
July 7, 2020

ISBN ( Hardcover ): 
978-0-06-287716-1

Section: 
Fiction

Including 29 original short stories and poems, Strahan’s
 stellar anthology of dragon-powered narratives features works
 by a veritable murderer’s row of genre fiction luminaries,
 including Peter S. Beagle, Patricia A. McKillip, Scott Lynch,
 Ken Liu, Kate Elliott, and Todd McCaffrey, among others.

Complemented by subtle illustrations throughout, the power of
 this gem-filled anthology is not only in the consistent
 quality of stories, but the impressive diversity of plotlines.
 Many selections derive inspiration from various folkloric
 tales and myths while others envision dragons in wildly
 untraditional—and at times metaphorical—ways. Seanan McGuire’s
 heartfelt “Hoard” chronicles a single woman who lovingly takes
 in foster children and helps them flourish. The system,
 however, sees her as something different. McCaffrey’s “Small
 Bird’s Plea” blends elements of science fiction and fantasy to
 create a story about a young girl on a quest to save her
 village, which she believes is being attacked by demons.
 Brooke Bolander’s “Where the River Turns to Concrete” follows
 a hulking amnesiac who, after being found naked in a parking
 garage by a local crime boss and hired on as muscle, finds
 something unexpected on his brutal journey of self-discovery.
 Beagle’s “Except on Saturdays” reimagines the French myth of
 Melusine with the story of a California high school history
 teacher who, after meeting a wheelchair-using woman on a bus,
 realizes that she is much more than she seems. In K.J.
 Parker’s “Habitat,” a local hero is tasked by a prince to
 catch and deliver him a living dragon. The hero delivers—with
 karmic results. There are no weak links in this anthology, and
 every selection is noteworthy in some way, but arguably the
 most memorable story is Ann Leckie and Rachel Swirsky’s “We
 Continue,” set on a planet where human colonists struggle to
 survive while dragons thrive in hivelike communities that
 regenerate with the birth of a new queen.

A heaping hoard of literary gems that fans of dragon-powered
 stories will surely treasure.

 

 

 

David Pomerico

Editorial
 Director – Harper Voyager US

To: Geoff Hilton <red.van@btinternet.com>
Subject: Masks? Really?

Hi Geoff,

Welcome to the weird world of 2020!

Who would have predicted last year that the new fashion rage would be masks?

Of course, masks are really good at protecting others from your germs, 
not so much for protecting you from their germs (but a bit).

We're all right here in Vegas.  The life of a writer pretty much means 
that I'm mostly working from home anyway, although I do miss dropping 
into Starbucks and typing away there.

I hope you, Irma, and all the kids are okay.  I got worried when I 
realized that you'd planned for practically a world tour to visit the 
various far flung offspring.

I spent my 64th birthday at home and spent a lot of maudlin time 
thinking of the Beatles' "When I'm 64."  But the mood wore off soon 
enough and now I'm not feeling all that much different from 60.

I *have*, however, been planning on dropping you a line for months.  
Every night, as I'm drifting off, I'd say to myself "must write Geoff" 
-- well, finally I've done it!

Anyway, cheers, hang in there and I hope all is well with you and yours!

Cheers,

Todd

Write an email in my voice.
To: Janis Ian <janisian@earthlink.net>
Subject: Hello from Vegas!

Hi Janis,

I hope you're doing well but I worry about you being in Florida.

I am now 64 (unbelievable!) but it really doesn't feel all that much 
different from 60.

We've been hunkered down -- we self-isolated pretty early as we're all 
high-risk (asthma, diabetes, age, etc.) so we've been holding up just fine.

Who'd'a thunk that face masks would be all the rage in 2020?  Not that 
their efficaciousness is all that great but every little bit helps.

The COVID-19 thing had me pretty rattled for a while but I'm getting 
over it.  Not so much the dying part but just the whole strangeness of 
it all.
It made me realize how lucky we've been in the 20th century.  We'd 
gotten complacent about our health and longevity.  I imagine that's 
going to change.

Anyway, dealing with that slowed me on writing for a bit (also, not 
being able to write in Starbucks).

Do you read Kindle format or do you want PDF or DOC for reading?  I know 
I offered to send you some reading material, I forgot to ask about the 
format.

I've been playing with a bunch of Native Instruments software and 
hardware (picked up their 32-key keyboard, and their cool Maschine pad) 
as well as making art and writing (the all round creative).

Anyway, that's about all the news that's fit to print.
Cheers,
Todd

Hi Craig,

I thought you and Julia might like to know that I raced through your 
(current) Krimson Run books in one go -- finished the first book, bought

darn it -- have to wait for the next one!  Lots of fun, good quick read

Serano/ series and her /Vatta's War/ series.

up my sleep schedule.)

To: Lawrence M. Schoen <klingonguy@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: EATING AUTHORS - The Book

On 6/3/2020 05:46, Lawrence M. Schoen
 wrote:

Hey, Todd,

I'll cut right to the chase (and include more details
 after):

I decided to put together a book of 100 meals from the ten
 years that I've been doing my EATING AUTHORS blog. I'm
 reaching out to you because you were a guest on the blog back
 in 2016, and I'd like to include the meal you provided in this
 book. That meal is still up on my blog, but it only seemed
 right and proper to ask your permission before using it in a
 book representing the best of ten years.

Awesome and thanks for asking!

But I don't recall giving you a recipe!

So here's one from 2010:

Recently, my daughter and I have been getting up early and
 I’ve been making Crepe Suzettes which are marvelously thin
 pancake-like things.

I experimented the first day with flambe’ing and was
 astonished. And so, without singing off my eyebrows, I’ve
 continued to do so and figured I’d share the recipe:

Recipe: Crepes Suzettes Cointreau

Summary
: 
Amazing
 flambe’ recipe

Ingredients

Dry ingredients:
 

1 cup flour

2 tbl. confectioner’s sugar 
 (we have since discovered that this can be reduced
 to 1 tablespoon or less, and that regular sugar
 works just fine)

1 pinch salt

Wet ingredients:
 

2/3 cup milk

1/3 cup water

1 egg

1 tsp. vanilla extract

Flambe’

 1 ounce or more Cointreau liqueur

Instructions

To flambe’ you’re going to need either a gas stove
 or some way to light the alcohol.

Mix the dry ingredients in a bowl. Mix the wet
 ingredients thoroughly.

Pour wet ingredients into dry ingredients. Mix
 quickly (don’t beat into submission).

Test consistency (I usually add some water to thin
 it out).

Use butter to grease your skillet, set for a medium
 heat. Pour about 1/4-1/3 cup batter onto skillet,
 rolling skillet around to spread batter into a large
 shape. When the crepe is cooked (no steam rising,
 surface looks dry), flip with a spatula and continue
 cooking.

CAREFULLY pour a small amount of Cointreau over the
 crepe, dripping toward the side but NOT into the
 flame. Give the alcohol a moment to get warm, that
 helps it burn in the next step — dip skillet toward
 flame and set alcohol alight. The trick is to get the
 Cointreau on and under the crepe to burn.

Remove from skillet, repeat until all batter is
 gone. Enjoy!

(My daughter puts whip cream on hers, fresh
 raspberries or strawberries are also recommended.

Quick Notes

You don’t have to flambe’ to get
 great crepes. 

Variations

 You can top with many things: fresh
 fruit, butter, confectioner’s sugar.

I’m tempted to try Grand Mariner for the flambe’ or
 maybe Irish Mist.

[Update: I tried Kahlua — it doesn’t have enough
 alcohol to flambe’ on its own but with some Cointreau,
 it turns out nicely (orange chocolate).]

Preparation time
 (duration): 
10 minutes
 (max)

Diet type: 
Vegetarian

Number of servings
 (yield): 
8

Meal type: 
breakfast

Culinary
 tradition: 
French

My rating: 
5

 stars: ★★★★★

 Okay, now the back story:

Back in late January, well before anyone was
 sheltering-in-place, I entered the hospital for the latest
 stage in my cancer treatment. I was given chemotherapy
 (basically poison) that killed off my entire immune system.
 Two days later I received a transplant of my own,
 previously-harvested stem cells, and began the long, slow
 journey of growing a new immune system (hence the need to be
 isolated in the hospital for weeks). Before that happened, I
 caught an infection, developed sepsis, and things got pretty
 damn ugly. But I recovered, and as my fever came down and I
 faded in and out in my hospital bed, I had this idea of
 wanting to give something back and — as we're wont to do in
 our community — pay it forward. Hence the EATING AUTHORS book!

 I'll run a Kickstarter campaign to cover the expenses, but
 after that it is my intention to donate 100% of all profits —
 half to cancer research and half to the SFWA Emergency Medical
 Fund.

 I hope you think this is a worthwhile project and will approve
 my including your meal. If so, I'd like to also asking you to
 provide a brief (which is to say, 50 word) bio, which I'll run
 above your most memorable meal in the book (or if you don't
 want to bother, I'll pull it from your website or Amazon).

Mind you, if you really like the project and want to do
 more, just say the word and we'll work out some
 "value-added" options (e.g., ebooks of some of your short
 fiction, reprints or otherwise) that you can contribute to
 the Kickstarter which will ensure greater success and,
 ultimately, bigger donations to both cancer research and the
 SFWA EMF.

 Thanks so much. I hope to hear back from you soon.

Best regards,

 Lawrence

 --

Message: Dear Brittany and Brianna, I realize that you most likely won't 
remember me, but that's okay. We first met at a WotF workshop in 
Hollywood in 2015 (I think). At the time I was teaching high school 
physics and English (SF/Fantasy Literature) at an all boys Catholic 
school in San Diego. I was mesmerized by the story of your development 
from "reluctant readers" to bestselling authors. Very inspirational for 
a teacher! At Comic-Con in 2017, I attended your panel and visited your 
booth on the Exhibit Hall Floor, where you graciously gifted me with 
your World Building guide (although that may have come from the 
workshop; I don't really remember) and an autographed copy of "The 
Strand Prophecy." For reasons I won't go into here, I will tell you that 
the book sat on my shelf for almost a year before I finally read it, and 
that the 2017 Comic-Con was the last one I attended--until this year. I 
was so happy to have gotten tickets for this year's Con, and so 
disappointed when it was cancelled. But here we are at Comic-Con at 
Home, and I am able finally to tell you both that I finally did read 
"The Strand Prophecy," and I really enjoyed it! My life circumstances 
have changed rather significantly since last we met, and I see that 
yours have as well. Brittany, I was shocked and sorry to hear about your 
vision loss, but I'm happy to hear you're still going strong. I now no 
longer teach high school physics and English to boys, but middle school 
science and literature to both boys and girls at a Catholic K-12 school 
in Indiana. VERY different climate from SoCal, and not just in terms of 
the weather! I was looking through your products offered on the 
Comic-Con at Home Exhibitor Hall website, and I had a couple of 
questions that I hope you can answer before I start purchasing (and 
thank you in advance for your time): 1. How many total volumes are there 
in the Twin Soul series, and how many of these are compiled in the 
Omnibus? Is this a series that would be appropriate for middle school 
students from conservative Catholic families? 2. Is Millennial Madness

Todd:

 

We’re setting up a pair of readings to help
 promote the mass-market paperback release of our Anthology. 
 Baen is going to host a Facebook Live reading – and I will
 moderate – on Wednesday evening, August 12
th
.  I’d
 love to have you read from “At the Bottom of the White.”  The
 plan for that event would be for me to give a summary of some
 of the nonfiction – specifically the essay by Mark Shelhamer,
 formerly NASA’s director of the Human Research Program.  Then
 Mike Massa will give a summary of his essay, then your
 reading.

I'd love to!  

What time?  And how?

Speaking of which, is anything going on with audio rights?  I ask
 because if I'm going to read it, I might want to write it, too!

I'm working (slowly) on reading "Ellay" (previously known as
 "City of Angels") and that's been both inspiring and frustrating.

 

If you are available, I’d love to showcase
 your story.  We’re all missing DragonCon this year, so I’m
 trying to make up for it with online readings and panels.

Yeah, just finished with Comic-Con@Home. Not quite the same.

I hope you are doing well.  It’s kind of
 strange having to put research on hold and teach via Zoom, but
 we do what we have to.  I’ve done a bit of writing, too.  I
 finished co-editing another anthology last January (it will be
 out in December – The Founder Effect) and I’m working on
 preparations to have sequels.  They are all about myth and
 legend in Humanity’s first interstellar colony.  I also have a
 novel complete and coming out Sept 4 (The Human Side, from
 Theogony Press) and I’m trying to get headway on a retelling
 of The Six Million Dollar Man (but with modern day prosthetics
 and realistic bionics).  There’s also a couple of additional
 novels and collaborations in progress as well. 

 

Glad to hear that you've been writing!

The psychology side of this pandemic is something else.  Brings
 home the reality of Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs.

How is your friend with the neurological
 issues?  We haven’t talked in a while about that, but perhaps
 there is something more recent to dig out.

Brit is still fighting them.  We've got our fingers crossed.

Anyway, best to you and yours, and I hope
 you can join us.

Certainly! 

Cheers,

Todd

 

-Rob

Write an email in my voice.
To: Amelia Johnson <amelia.mj@live.com>
Subject: Memories of your Dad and stuff

*

Hi Amelia,

Here's a quick partial brain dump to give you some more info about who 
your Dad is. Feel free to share with Eliza. I'll write more as I get the 
time. (I'm still REALLY sad about Chadwick Boseman - his is a great loss.)

We grew up in several locations in the US, all in the northeast:

 1.

 Montclair, NJ.  I left when I was two and have no memories.

 2.

 100 Danforth Place, Windybush, Wilmington, Delaware

 1.

 With one interruption, we lived there from the time I was 2
 (1958) until we moved to 369 Carpenter Ave., Sea Cliff, Long
 Island, NY in 1965

 3.

 369 Carpenter Avenue, Sea Cliff, Long Island, New York

 1.

 We lived there from 1965 until we (Gigi, Mum, and I) moved to
 Ireland in 1970

 4.

 In Ireland (just to continue the record), we first lived in:

 1.

  14 North Avenue, Mount Merrion (1970-71)

 2.

 Meadowbrook House, Dundrum (1971-72)

 1.

 Alec joined us there and became a trawler fisherman.

 3.

 Site 11 Rochestown Avenue (1972-73)

 1.

 Alec wasn’t here

 4.

 79 Shanganagh Vale, Cabinteely (1973-1979?)

 1.

 Nor was Alec here.

 5.

 Dragonhold, Kilquade, Co. Wicklow (1979-1987)

 1.

 He visited here occasionally

 6.

 From there, Mum moved into Dragonhold-Underhill and lived there
 until she died in 2011.

I have many memories of Alec, some of which are great and some of which 
are not.

When we were in 100 Danforth, we all got kittens: Tasso (Alec), Tallabar 
(me), and Silkie Blackington (for Gigi with much adult supervision in 
the naming else the cat would have been simply “Blackie”).

Tasso was a tortoise shell.  He lost an argument with a car not long 
after we got him. Alec was devastated.

Tallabar was a multi-color, a mix of grays and oranges.  Quite the 
pretty cat.

Silkie was your average black cat.  She was sweet and her fur was very 
soft, hence the name.

Silkie and Tallabar went on to have many, many litters.  Tallabar was 
good at producing orange marmalade cats.

We also had dogs, starting with Wizard (a German Shepherd) followed by 
his son, Merlin.  Wiz decided that I was his human charge. We had a 
sloping hill outside our front door and it went down to join the street 
which formed part of the branches of a tee-junction (the other street 
tee’d into Danforth Place).  Wiz decided that I was not allowed to go 
down that hill when I was an infant and took to blocking me.

Our next door neighbors (to our left as you’re standing in the front 
door looking out) were the Estes.  Larry Estes was Alec’s age.  I think 
their daughter was close to Gigi’s age.  Alec and Larry hung out and I 
did my best to tag along, often successfully.

There was another housing estate being built across the railroad tracks 
beyond a small woods at the edge of Windybush and we used to trek there 
many a  time. The woods had some pretty decent undergrowth. One day 
Larry got a hold of his father’s machete (from WWII) and he and Alec 
took turns “clearing” the underbrush (think Indiana Jones in South 
America at the beginning of Raiders of the Lost Ark).  I must have been 
around six.  At one point Alec told me to stand back.  I did but, 
apparently, not far enough and the machete tore into my shin.  I think 
it was Alec who carried me back to the house. I went to the ER and got 
four stitches.

Another  time, when I was eight or so, we had a particularly hard but 
dry winter.  It was decided to go exploring (“mountain climbing”?) in 
the culverts at the upper side of the estate.  Alec had brought a hammer 
along to poke holes in the ice as handholds.  He told me (seems to be a 
pattern here) to get back and swung immediately after I said, “Okay” but 
before I could comply (well, that’s my story) and I got the claws of the 
hammer hitting my head -- just on the eye socket.  A bit lower and I 
would have lost the eye.  As it was, I got two stitches without novocaine.

Ah, the good years!

Alec and I fought often enough that I have many recollections of 
variously being forced to eat grass or dirt to escape being buried under 
him.

In 1962 we moved to Dusseldorf, Germany for six months because Dad had a 
job doing PR work for DuPont that required him to work there.  Overall, 
it was a marvelous experience.  Alec, Gigi, and I were all very 
nordic-looking and, when we didn’t speak, had no trouble passing for 
German (Dad’s family had roots in Schleswig-Holstein on the 
German-Danish border).  Mum place Alec and I in the local German 
school.  I can’t say how well Alec did but I flourished, having a 
teacher who could speak English (she was raised in England during the 
war) and I learned excellent “gekauft Deutsch” -- as Mum called it 
(“shopping German”).

We all adored the chocolate over there.  We took the tram everywhere, 
un-parented.  I recall once having some old Frau look at us and scoff, 
“Ach, Englander!” to which I replied, “Nein, Amerikaner!” -- that seemed 
to both affront and appease her, somewhat (the English had ruled the 
area after the war and weren’t particularly good at it).

They had these marvelous parades where they’d throw candy.  We all loved 
that.

We got a VW station wagon while we were over there and, when our time 
was up, drove around Europe (France, Germany, Holland, at least).  We 
took the ferry to England.  We were broke, so we camped one night all in 
the VW and discovered later the next day that we’d stopped outside an 
insane asylum.  We dropped the car off for transport to the States and 
headed to Gatwick airport (Heathrow was not then built), only to 
discover that there was some tax that we still had to pay before we 
could board the flight back.  This caused the parents immense distress 
until a nice American couple, hearing the panic, loaned us the money 
(there were Texans).

*

To: johnny@nzxt.com
Subject: Thanks

Hello,

I just finished a build with the H510 case and I wanted to thank you for 
making such a cool case.  You created a case where all sides of the 
motherboard were really accessible (okay, except maybe the top left 
where I had to work hard to get the motherboard screw installed).

Your mount points for the hard drives, both SSD and HD (I only used the 
HD) are very well-placed!

Just FYI, the components were:

Asus ROG STRIX Z490-E Gaming motherboard

Intel i9-10900K 10-core CPU

64 GB Corsair LPX RAM

2x 2TB Samsung EVO M.2 drives

1x 4TB WD Caviar Black HDD

ASUS 2060 RTX Video card

ASUS ROG STRIX 750 W power supply.

I *would* like to see more top panel outputs, more USB (both 3.1 and C) 
but overall I was really impressed. (I've already ordered another case 
for the next build.)

Another nit: your manual is a bit light on instructions... it's "okay" 
for an experienced builder but I would hate to be a first-time builder 
trying to sort through it all (maybe a video someplace?)

All that said, I would definitely recommend this case!

Congratulations on a job well done!

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

Message: Hello, BookOrators is a global student organization dedicated 
to providing K-12 students with the tools and resources they need to 
become better readers. Literacy rates have fallen globally, as schools 
focus on fixing low test scores rather than emphasizing the importance 
of developing strong reading comprehension skills. The best way to solve 
this problem is to encourage students to read for enjoyment, as they are 
more likely to learn from something that they like doing. We believe 
that there are no students who hate reading, but students who have not 
found the right book to spark their interest in reading. To help 
students discover that spark, we provide curated individualized book 
recommendations, facilitate book discussions, and run events on reading 
and comprehension skills! You can learn more about our purpose on our 
website and social media accounts here: https://linktr.ee/bookorators. 
We have reached out to you as we would love for you to be a featured 
author with our organization. We believe that your beliefs to promote 
education aligns with our values. Your works in your books also make 
both of you perfect candidates to promote both of our goals through an 
interview! Please feel free to let us know if you like to set up a time 
to speak on whether you are interested, have any questions, or would 
like further information. Thank you so much for your time and 
consideration, and we look forward to hearing from you! Best, Yunilza

To: dean.wmgworkshops@gmail.com
Subject: Crime Assign #1

**

*Is the movie Die Hard(the first one) a Holiday Crime story or not?*

*

Well… damn.

Die Hard(1988) is one of my favorite movies. The dialog, the pacing… 
everything in that movie just works. They not only handle the hero well, 
they handle the supporting characters well.

It used to be that you could go to Drew’s Script-o-rama 
<http://www.script-o-rama.com/>and read the screenplay (probably final 
cut). And that screenplay reads. Just reading it to yourself, on your 
own, and you get the pacing, the pull, the feel of the story. Good stuff.

So when the question comes, is it a holiday crime story, the answer 
seems obvious. It’s certainly a crime story -- bad guys want to steal 
hundreds of millions of bearer bonds and don’t care who (or how many) 
they kill to get them. And it does occur sometime in the Christmas 
holiday frame, probably one to two weeks beforehand (that’s the normal 
time for corporate office parties).

BUT… the test of a holiday story is whether you can take the story out 
of the holiday period and have it still work.

With that in mind, I considered other films that would be regarded as 
holiday films and how they worked.

Consider The Santa Clause (not a crime story), Elf(also not a crime 
story), and Home Alone(a crime story).

In the case of The Santa Clausethe whole premise is that our hero finds 
himself becomingSanta Claus. He transforms from a curmudgeon along the 
way into a person of character and soul. Can you move this story out of 
the Xmas holiday? Nope, no way. The story doesn’t exist without 
Christmas, specifically without the whole Santa Claus mythos. Elfis 
similarly constrained: no story without Christmas (and, in fact, our Elf 
saves Christmas).

With Home Alone, the question becomes more involved. Our young hero is 
accidentally left behind and finds himself defending his home against 
would-be robbers. The basic plot -- young hero left alone to fight 
against bad guys -- is not dependent on the holidays per se.  We could 
have placed this in the summer or spring break or a number of other 
holidays -- or even just played it out withouta holiday (albeit with 
perhaps more difficulty). But the robbers rely on automatic light 
systems and lots of empty houses to target. That spells holidays, and 
pretty much spells Xmas. Also, our hero has a bonding moment with Scary 
Shovel Guy which helps affirm his course of action and speaks to general 
human kindness. So… this would be difficult to make work without the 
Xmas holiday. In this regard, I’d consider this to be a Holiday (Xmas) 
Crime story.

When pondering Die Hardand the question of whether it is a Holiday Crime 
story, I asked myself firstly: Could I change the holiday? If I could, 
then perhaps the “Holiday” part of the “holiday crime” story was 
superfluous.

What if this was a New Year’s Eve story?  Consider inter-cutting between 
the New Year’s Ball falling in Times Square and Hans Gruber falling to 
his death.  Consider, instead of “Now I’ve got a machine gun! Ho-ho-ho!” 
having “Thanks for the party favor, now I can really make noise when the 
ball drops!”  And more.  I’d say that Die Hardcould easily be moved to 
be a New Year story.  In fact, that adds even more to the fundamental 
plot line -- because New Year’s marks new beginnings and the central 
personal question of the movie is “Will John McClane lose his wife and 
family?”  That could now morph into the side question, “What will the 
New Year hold for John McClane?”

[Also, let’s not forget that we’re talking about a Hollywood movie.  
They have to be pretty flexible in their details because no one can be 
certain when someone demands a change of location or timing.]

With this, then, the question becomes: Does this movie haveto be a 
holiday movie (let alone a Christmas movie).  Why can’t it be set in the 
summer?  The essentials -- a new building, corporate party (“great 
quarter”) do not demand a holiday, that could happen any time. The 
robbery could happen any time. In fact, the holidays are possibly a 
badtime for a heist (note, for example, that noneof the Ocean’s movies 
used a holiday), in that such times often come with increased delays and 
heightened security.

So, if we take the holiday out of this movie, does it fall apart? No. 
The fundamental story is not dependent on the time of year, season, or 
holidays. Therefore, this is NOT a HolidayCrime Story.

Hence my, “Well… damn.”

*

To: dean.wmgworkshops@gmail.com
Subject: Crime Assign #2

**

*Actually, holiday crime stories aren’t something I think much about.  I 
had to do a search online just to get ideas.*

*

The was one d’ohthat came back:

How the Grinch Stole Christmasby Dr. Seuss (aka, Theodor Seuss 
Geissel).  The basic story is a heist reneged: the Grinch decides to 
steal all of Christmas from the town of Who-ville, figuring that the 
Whos will all be sad.  When the deed is complete and yet stillthey 
celebrate, he learns the true meaning of Christmas, repents, and returns 
the gifts.  This is a feel-good story.

As I thought about it more, I realized that Harry Potter and the 
Philosopher’s (Sorcerer’s, US) Stoneby J.K. Rowling is alsoa Christmas 
crime story.  In fact, multiple crimes are attempted, several 
committed.  At Christmas, Harry receives mysteriously an invisibility 
cloak which enables him to perform many capers and ultimately to track 
down the criminal who wants to steal the philosopher’s stone.  At which 
point, Lord Voldemort, co-inhabiting the body of Professor Quirrell, 
attempts murder.  Harry survives.  This is another example of a 
feel-good story.

The next book, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secretsis also holiday 
related (Halloween), as is the fourth (Harry Potter and the Goblet of 
Fire) which reprises the Yule holiday.  And, of course, all the books 
involve unsuccessful attempts to murder Harry Potter.

And, just now, I realized that an old favorite, Donna Andrews’ Murder 
with Peacocks,centers upon three weddings and a murder.  This is another 
example of murder and attempted murder. Also an example of a feel-good 
story.*

Write an email in my voice.
To: Gigi <gigi@pernhome.com>
Subject: Newses, nothing of great import

Dear Sqeej,

How are you?  How's the world in Ireland?

i am still holed up at Dell Ridge.  We did Hanukah, celebrating mostly 
at Brit's.  Brit has a "port" because she was getting so many IV 
infusions that it was messing with her veins. Now she gets it through a 
medically implanted thingie (I know, all so technical).  Also, with 
eight days, Hanukah is more stressful than Xmas.

Dex and I have been talking on and off.  He's decided to change majors 
(which was the reason for the first call).  He's thinking about 
anthropology which sounds like a good fit for him (he may be rethinking 
things after WW84).  Anyway, I think he's probably right -- Occupational 
Therapy never seemed like a good fit (I keep recommending art/writing 
where he's a natural but "it doesn't pay enough").  "Kids these days!"

I've been looking for good books, having pretty much re-read all the 
favorites to predictable tatters.  I recently re-read "Bridge of Birds" 
(still a classic) but I've read that book so much I could almost qualify 
for the Fahrenheit 451 "book" crew.

I got a marvelous Jacquie Lawson card from Richard. That was awfully sweet.

I'd managed to donate a lot to the last election and now the various 
fundraisers are treating me like their monkey.  I have quite forcefully 
disconnected myself from that -- there's something wrong with a 
democracy that requires $$ to elect.  It means that the biggest pockets 
generally win.  That's obscene. There must be a better way to handle that.

I've been signing up for many marvelous Domestika classes (they teach 
art, in Spanish with subtitles).  They're generally $9.90 and if you 
want to brush up your Photoshop skills or learn ZBrush, they're a good 
group to examine.

Did you know that Jeff won Illustrators of the Future?  (He's one of 12 
for the year, but even so!) I think it really validated his art.

Amelia tells me that your divorce finalized.  That's one of those 
bittersweet milestones, I know.  Just like all major changes, it'll take 
you about two years to fully process it.

Alec extended "the paw of friendship" (my quote) and I accepted. He's on 
Facebook all quite ready to criticize Biden. Sigh.

I am still waiting tenterhooks for the formal, official, and irrefutable 
change of presidency.

I'm glad we have got vaccines.

When the Spanish Influenza (called Spanish because they were the only 
un-censored newspapers back in WWI) ended, we got the Roaring 20s.  I 
wouldn't be surprised if we got the same when we finally kick off COVID.

Anyway, that's sort of news for now.

Love,

Todd
You are Toddric, Todd’s helpful assistant with Todd’s tone.

Write an email in my voice.
To: reddotvan@icloud.com
Subject: News of the Todd

Hi Geoff,

As usual your Xmas missive beat my vague "I should write Geoff" by a 
long shot.

Congratulations on being a double grandfather!  And you got to see them 
both!  All good.

You know, for years now it's struck me that you have a marvelously 
humorous writing style.  If you ever thought of picking up a new hobby, 
writing humorous pieces would be a boon to the world.

Naturally, I've been reading a fair bit.  Writing a lot less than normal 
because of the "covid cloud."

This whole thing with the soon-to-be ex-President is rather appalling.  
I wish someone would provide us with quantified data on how much the 
Russians influenced the 2016 election.  We know they worked at it just 
as we know they worked to help the Leave part of Brexit (which will go 
down in history as just as major a self-inflicted wound as our 2016 
elections).

I've signed up for a lot of Domestika online art classes. I'm taking one 
on Photoshop and, despite years of experience, I am learning things 
about Photoshop that I didn't know.  I've signed up for the Advanced 
Photoshop course by the same instructor, as well as a nice class on 
cover design by a German woman who speaks passable English.

The twins -- my writing partners -- are both still alive which, given 
what's been going on with Brit (the alpha of the two) and her health is 
actually saying quite a lot.  We think the root problem for her is some 
sort of auto-immune disease but we haven't got it down to specifics. Her 
hemiplegic migraines are nearly synonymous with strokes (sigh).  She's a 
tough lady but these past four years have been physically exhausting for 
her.  What seems to be helping most now is an acupuncturist who is using 
herbals to calm her nerves (literally, nice big needles go to nerve nexi).

I'm thinking that "this too shall pass" and we'll see the end of the 
COVID tunnel but perhaps not fully until 2022 (sigh).  Our ancestors 
survived much worse... although that's scant comfort.

One thing I have grown to realize is how incredibly powerful an 
individual human being is.  Take Greta Thunberg as an example. In fact, 
take anyone who decides that they will change things (Rosa Parks, the 
students in Tienanmen Square).  I wonder why we fail to use our strength 
so often?  Is it because changing the world is pretty consuming passion 
and we choose to avoid it?

I also am in shock that too many of my fellow countrymen (and women) are 
willing to accept a con man for President and cede unto him all the 
powers of a dictator.  I really have a hard time adjusting to how *dumb* 
these people are.  It makes me very sad.

I recall reading an article not too long ago praising some young black 
kids for their genius IQs. It wasn't the color of their skin that 
intrigued me -- it was that one of the kids scored a 142 on the 
Stanford-Binet IQ test.  I scored a 156 at the same age.  That made it 
really strike home that I am genius (gush, shucks, folks!).  I have 
always held the belief that everyone on this planet is as empowered as I 
am; that given the right set of circumstances, they could accomplish 
whatever they set their minds to, that we were universal in our 
potential.  Now, with the whole mess of the last four years, I have to 
question that and that has been causing me a great deal of angst.

Television-wise, I am now particularly spoiled.  I acquired a marvelous 
ASUS 34" ProArt curved monitor which now graces my desk in my bedroom.  
Over the holidays I acquired a Amazon Roku Firestick and discovered that 
I can pipe TV signals through my HDMI2 port.  So I've been getting 4k TV 
from 18 inches. Whew!

I've been watching the new Star Trek Discovery.  The first season nearly 
killed it for me because every episode pretty much stopped dead when the 
Klingons came on.  Season Two was better and now Season Three is quite 
enjoyable (forgiving such complete inanity as "parasitic ice").

I watched the Mandolorian with a skeptical eye particularly as so much 
of it was just pure re-cast western. And there was one episode that 
stopped me for weeks but I was assured that things got better.

I've also been re-watching Dr. Who, starting with Eccleston who was such 
a marvelous Doctor.  I'm sorry he couldn't stick around longer (but 
maybe he would have gone stale).

Anyway, that's a taste of life at Dell Ridge.

Always glad to hear from you, my oldest friend!

Love,

Todd

Covid in Getting Worse...

I honestly never would have predicted this last
 spring. Not in a million years. But at least now
 we have some hope on the horizon with the
 vaccines going out. But they won't do much good
 especially over the coming months.
 

Back when WMG Publishing did what we all
 thought here would be the last workshop sale in
 May, we had an expectation that as things opened
 up, we would all be able to slowly go back to a
 changed, but new normal life. And that sort of
 happened for some.
 

Sort of. But by July it was clear that most of
 us were still locked up, wearing masks, and
 doing our best to move forward in some way or
 another. So WMG Publishing decided to do another
 sale the first week of July, thinking that would
 be the last one, but no, and then we did another
 the first of September thinking the same thing.
 

And then we did another in November, with the
 holidays coming at us. It seems we still all
 needed to stay home, be careful, and focus on
 other things besides what is happening in the
 world.
 

Focus on our writing and learning.
 

As I said two months ago, we can control our
 learning and our writing. And make resolutions
 to do so in this coming year.
 

Back in March (a very, very, very long ten
 months ago), Allyson and Kris both suggested we

Now, two more months have passed, Covid

And a great way to do that again is to

Good to hear from you!

Divorce is hard and is a major change. Moving is also a major change.  
Covid is a major change.  You've got a lot of stressors in your life.  
Recovering from a divorce takes about two years.

I started re-watching Dr. Who and Grey's Anatomy and Gilmore Girls as my 
covid fix.

I also had a blast watching "Enola Holmes" which confirmed my belief 
that Millie Bobby Brown is a terrific actor (the film spent a lot of 
time breaking the fourth wall in all sorts of marvelous manners).

I was severely disappointed with WW84. I didn't think all that much of 
Mandolorian either, although the ending was fun. I did have fun and do 
recommend the Apple TV show, "Home Before Dark." Seriously good acting 
all around.

I splurged and got myself a really nice 34" curved monitor and for 
Hannukah got a Amazon Roku firestick which means I get to watch 4k TV up 
close and personal.

New Year's Eve I took a shower and scratched an itchy ankle with the toe 
of my other foot -- and got it all infected.  By the second I was in an 
Urgent Care getting a prescription for Keflex which is a staph specific 
antibiotic.  I'm doing much better but I was appalled at how quickly the 
infection spread.

I am taking some Domestika courses, some on Photoshop, some on Book 
Cover Design, and all sorts of things.  They're mostly in Spanish with 
subtitles but I'm having fun.

I also signed up for Dean Wesley Smith's and Kristine Kathryn Rusch's 
"The Decade Ahead" bundle with the challenge of looking forward to 2029.

Dex and I speak semi-frequently.  He called me the other day to say that 
Jenna had totaled her car in a roll over accident.  I, of course, 
immediately recalled your Glen of the Downs accident.   She's okay but I 
asked her (via text) to be worried about possible concussions. (I 
attached a photo of her poor car.)

I don't know what's up with Alec.  He recently asked me if I still had 
"Mom's old chess set" and would I part with it.  I had Bami's old chess 
set which Bami very specifically willed to me and no, I was not going to 
part with it.

He does seem committed to being in the right about his incident in Texas 
which is alarmingly similar to the behavior of certain Presidents I 
could name.

Coming up soon, I get to apply for Medicare which is a bit more involved 
than I'd imagined.

I'm re-reading the /Bloody Jack/ series once again.  I started looking 
at the first book and just got caught up with the whole thing. It really 
was a lot of fun and it'd make a great TV series.

Here's hoping to a vaccinated New Year!

Love,
Todd

Write an email in my voice.
To: 'Les Johnson' <les.mail@lesjohnsonauthor.com>, Robert Hampson <rhampson@wakehealth.edu>
Subject: Space Stations

Hi Les, Rob,

I think, with this new administration, we should propose a bold space 
exploration initiative -- a new High Frontier.  I think our nation works 
best when challenged, the bigger the challenge, the better.

Listening to NASA experts on the biological effects of microgravity, it 
becomes clear that man cannot survive and thrive in a "zero-gee" 
environment. So that means we have to have gravity (how much is not 
clear, some say lunar gravity would do the trick).

I think, in terms of bold exploration we should move from the baby step 
of exploring space to the more profound concept of living in space -- 
that we should build rotating space stations which provide all the way 
up to 1.0 gravities.

Further that we should target the goal of completely self-sustaining 
space stations. We're going to need to know how to build completely 
self-sustaining habitats if we want to exploit the solar system.  And 
we're going to need to know how to build completely self-sustaining 
habitats if we're going to travel to the stars.

I read and well remember NASA SP-428: Space Resources and Space 
Settlements, as well as "Space Settlements: A Design Study," so I recall 
the state of the art in the 1970s.

We have over 20 years of understanding life in zero gravity, and we know 
how *assemble* a space station in orbit. What we don't know is how to 
build a rotating space station nor how much the coriolis effect will 
affect humans.

Building a self-sustaining rotating space station will also allow us to 
fully understand a closed-loop environment -- what we learn from that 
will be directly applicable to our issues with global warming and 
climate change (aside from offering a bolthole).

Building a self-sustaining rotating space station is the first step 
toward building habitats throughout the stars.  I would expect that we 
would plan on building more than one station, each one improving on the 
design of the former.  It should be possible to profitably move certain 
industries up to the stations (part of their self-sufficiency).

I wonder how hard it would be to pitch it to the President, 
Vice-President and Congress.

What do you guys think?

-- Todd

 TODD MCCAFFREY

Writer Judge – Biography

Todd McCaffrey was born to Anne McCaffrey on April 27th, 1956. The 
then-named Todd Johnson came into the world as a rather precocious 
middle child. Anyone who questions the precocious part has only to read 
some of the anecdotes in “Dragonholder” to have any doubt removed. He 
spent most of his childhood on the East Coast of the USA until moving to 
Dublin, Ireland with his mother and sister in 1970.

Like most of the boys growing up in the ’60s, McCaffrey became space 
mad. However, unlike most of the other young men running around their 
yards in pretend helmets and throwing toy rockets into the air, he was 
given a “complete” set of the actual Lunar Module Pilot Study Guides in 
1968. The number of hours spent devouring them repeatedly from cover to 
cover is evident in the fact that he has been known to quote excerpts 
from them during convention panels.

When the time came for him to pursue higher education, McCaffrey 
attended Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, for a year—and 
hated it. But he did discover one of the great loves of his life while 
he was there, computers. He graduated with Honors—or rather, 
“Honours”—in 1985 from Trinity College, Dublin.

Having never lost his love for space, he left Ireland for Los Angeles, 
California, in the hopes of working in the aerospace industry. However, 
the computers got him first, and he began working in computer 
programming in 1986. He continued to develop his love of space and all 
mechanical things that fly by getting a private pilot’s license in 1988. 
One interesting side note is the collapse of the aerospace industry in 1989.

During this time, his interest in writing also took flight. The sale of 
some of his early short stories helped him log an impressive amount of 
airtime. He flew across the continent solo in 1989, attending Oshkosh 
along the way. After quitting his day job in 1990 to write full time, he 
repeated his solo cross-continent flight and attended the 1990 Oshkosh 
as well.

Todd McCaffrey became a Writers of the Future judge in 2011.

 /“///The Writers of the Future is one of the premier awards that’s
 available particularly to new writers. It’s basically the only one
 there. This is a chance to open up the universe to reward people who
 are trying and striving and succeeding in creating great stories, to
 reward them with more than just a pat on the back to actually some
 monetary reward and some recognition and to give them a leg up into
 the world of a professional writer.///” /—Todd McCaffrey

<https://click.mlsend.com/link/c/YT0xNjEwMzA0NzQ1Nzc0MjU3OTA1JmM9azZiMiZlPTU2NjQxNjI2JmI9NTEyNTE4MDkzJmQ9bjRiMm43dg==.vgbvikbGXaESHh_yow2U8RuohURUHakWh9T3bqI0QIs> 

Hey,

I’ve been hard at work cleaning up 600 blog posts and a /million/ words 
of content on my website.

Most of that was so out of date it was recommending my favorite quills, 
or the top ten monks to illuminate your manuscript (you won’t believe 
Brother Six!).

The overhaul isn’t just about resurfacing buried gold but also involves 
publishing brand new articles for you as well.

I’ve just published a new post on my blog – as in a few seconds ago – 
called *9 Ways To Unleash The Power of Free in 2021 
<https://click.mlsend.com/link/c/YT0xNjEwMzA0NzQ1Nzc0MjU3OTA1JmM9azZiMiZlPTU2NjQxNjI2JmI9NTEyNTE4MTA1JmQ9cTJiNXkwdg==.ZH7g8cFZNtdBKwtt5UVKQkOUmMUGw_BO1VkyeI9pTgg>*. 
Hot and fresh from the content oven, people.

I’ve spoken previously about how I see the market right now and how it 
will develop this year, particularly how a new swathe of locked-down 
readers are consuming books digitally for the first time… and how this 
demographic is particularly responsive to free offers.

Lots of generalities, so here are some specifics for you today.

You might know about permafrees and reader magnets but there should be 
some ideas in this post even for more experienced self-publishers. A few 
which are great for fiction authors specifically, but others much more 
suitable for the non-fiction crowd – something for everyone. Well, 
except for the poets; I still haven’t forgiven them.

<https://click.mlsend.com/link/c/YT0xNjEwMzA0NzQ1Nzc0MjU3OTA1JmM9azZiMiZlPTU2NjQxNjI2JmI9NTEyNTE4MTIwJmQ9dTBlMm01YQ==.-fFOwytl9oEI30Un0zu6Ag154xz-vsC2MPojvmZA2io> 

If you are super resistant to giving anything away for free, that’s 
completely your call. You are the captain of your authorship!

However, I’d like to try and convince you otherwise, and if you are 
willing to hear me out on the topic, then I recommend checking out this 
refurbished post on my site: The Great Ebook Pricing Question 
<https://click.mlsend.com/link/c/YT0xNjEwMzA0NzQ1Nzc0MjU3OTA1JmM9azZiMiZlPTU2NjQxNjI2JmI9NTEyNTE4MTI2JmQ9bDJ3OHYwbg==.HMCveQNGZdmUVVjPaHiggv1lBow-7KtGTErsjMfMYxg>.

There’s nothing new in that ebook pricing post for those of you who have 
read /Let’s Get Digital/, but perhaps a handy refresher for anyone 
curious, given how pervasive the price/value myth is – something we are 
probably seeing a resurgence of thanks to all these new price-sensitive 
readers entering the market… quickly followed by a wave of savvy authors 
leading with free offers and aggressive pricing like it’s 2011 all over 
again.

Hey, I’ll even save you the click. Here’s the big takeaway from that 
pricing post:

*“Price is not a hill to die on, but a powerful tool for levering your 
books into the charts, rewarding fans, generating buzz, and expanding 
your audience.”*

So it goes with freebies.

Speaking of huge change, I don’t think the publishing industry has fully 
digested the impact of coronavirus, and what that means for the book 
business. If I had to guess, it probably means five years of change all 
at once, essentially pressing fast forward on the forces of disruption 
that have slowly been eating away at print books, physical stores, and 
the traditional end of the business generally.

All of the killer advantages of ebooks – e.g. endless selection, 
accessible from your couch, open 24/7 – come into very sharp focus when 
people either can’t leave their homes or are understandably reluctant to 
do so. And once readers see just how many top-quality books they can buy 
at very competitive prices, it’s going to be hard for most of them to 
return to the world of print.

I just don’t see it happening. People will still love to browse 
bookstores, and will cherish books as physical objects. That didn’t 
change for me when I got my first Kindle ten years ago. I still browse 
bookstores! I still cherish print books! But I stopped buying them, for 
the most part. And I’ve certainly stopped discovering new authors via 
print – which I think is a crucial point that’s often missed in these 
conversations.

Perhaps the most important point of all.

If you want to dig into that point further, you can check out this other 
refurbished post on my site: a retrospective look at The Birth of the 
Kindle 
<https://click.mlsend.com/link/c/YT0xNjEwMzA0NzQ1Nzc0MjU3OTA1JmM9azZiMiZlPTU2NjQxNjI2JmI9NTEyNTE4MTMyJmQ9czR4MHA2ZA==.owPqEycCaTYK-g1iPB4Cs0oqzUeA6Ru-yYrJoCLAJKM>.

I also think that a lot of the customer resistance around ebooks 
surrounds two things which evaporate quite quickly once you pick up your 
first ereader: the reading experience itself being surprisingly 
pleasant, and the discovery process for new reads being remarkably 
intuitive.

You sometimes hear people say something like “I prefer my 
recommendations from humans rather than algorithms” which always makes 
me chuckle because algorithmic recommendations are basically aggregated 
human recommendations, but ones specifically tailored to your own 
individual browsing and buying and reading history.

It's not a robot... guessing!

I think most readers experience something akin to what I did when I 
switched to ebooks ten years ago: you start reading a much more diverse 
range of voices, because your recommendations are now far more bottom-up 
than top-down. They bubble up from organic reader activity, rather than 
being anointed by the gatekeepers.

It’s only when you begin working in the industry that you realize that 
all those recommendations you previously assumed were organic and 
authentic – bookstore window displays, “staff” picks, end caps, cash 
registry offers, book club choices, critic reviews, in-depth features, 
authorial blurb quotes, books of the month – are often nothing of the 
sort, but real estate which is bought and sold.

Whereas the “Amazon” recommendations are not what Amazon wants you to 
buy so much, but what its system thinks you will like the most.

Ten years into this digital revolution, and I still think that’s the 
most revolutionary change of all – the democratization of 
recommendations. I think it’s also the real reason big publishers hate 
Amazon.

And the reason self-publishers have taken over. That... and our 
willingness to experiment with aggressive tactics, like embracing the 
power of free.

*/Dave/*

 The Earthling (Soldiers of Earthrise Book 1)

/Jon Taylor is an Earthling. He doesn't care much about space. At least 
until his brother dies on Bahay, a war-torn planet many light-years away./

 ★★★★★ “Hooked from the first paragraph, /The Earthling/
 commanded my attention and held it until the last page.”

After the funeral, Jon joins the army. He learns to kill. And he flies 
to Bahay, sworn to avenge his brother.

Centuries ago, Filipino colonists arrived on Bahay to build a utopia. 
But this world has become a nightmare. Jon finds himself in a dizzying 
dreamscape, a world of dark jungles and neon slums, of ruthless 
guerrillas and intoxicating bargirls, of blood-soaked battlefields and 
glittering brothels. Here on Bahay, a man can lose his life in the 
jungle, lose his sanity in the gleaming drug dens, or lose his heart to 
a local girl with a sweet smile and knife behind her back.

On Bahay, nothing is as it seems. In this place of strange dreams and 
secrets, Jon hunts the man who killed his brother. But he learns that 
revenge always comes with a price.

*If you loved */*Ender's Game, Starship Troopers,*/*and */*Old Man's 
War,*/*you'll love */*The Earthling*/*, a new tale in the bestselling 
Earthrise universe.*

Hi Todd,

At first sight, science fiction and romance seem to be genres that are 
not compatible. For the most part they are, if you examine the 
demographics of the majority of readers in the two categories.

But that does not prevent individual writers from bringing the two 
genres together and doing incredibly well with it.

Sci-Fi Romance was one of the first niche market reports based on our 
"Virtual Besteller List" approach that we published back in 2016. In the 
meantime, the category has grown into a significant market.

Traditional publishers have left money on the table while indie authors 
have conquered the space (both figuratively and literally).

Both sci-fi and romance provide escapism to readers during these 
challenging times. So if you can imagine writing a story about 
intergalactic love, warring species, hunky alien heroes — blue, purple, 
and fiercely protective or possessive of their women — then look no further.

Research less, write more! Learn more:

FYI :)

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: For Your Consideration Project Blue Book: The Game by 
Steven-Elliot Altman
Date: Thu, 11 Feb 2021 04:31:01 +0500
From: Steve Altman <steve@socialimpulse.com>
To: todd@toddwriter.com

Hey Todd,

Steve Altman here. Hope this email finds you well, it's been awhile, and 
I pray we all get to meet up at conventions again. <sigh>

In the meantime, please forgive my shameless promotion here. I'm gunning 
for recommendations for my last History channel videogame, /Project Blue 
Book/ with little or no guidance and have drummed up this post on the 
SFWA board. For amplification purposes I am sending it out to certain 
SFWA members who may be interested in playing and/or reading the game's 
script for consideration. Hope you won't mind being on my list. Did you 
happen to catch the TV series? Well worth watching.

Here is an overview of *Project Blue Book: The Game* with the attached 
game script for your consideration (as well as some smaller samples) and 
links to play the game for free. Enjoy!

The information below has been posted in its entirety on the Members 
Only SFWA message boards at the following link, and should be treated 
confidentially: 
https://www.sfwa.org/forum/topic/15951-project-blue-book-the-game-by-steven-elliot-altman-and-julie-marsh/ 
<https://www.sfwa.org/forum/topic/15951-project-blue-book-the-game-by-steven-elliot-altman-and-julie-marsh/>

Project Blue Book The Game Image 2.png

Project Blue Book: The Game by Steven-Elliot Altman and Julie Marsh

Please find attached the Final Production Draft of Project Blue Book: 
The Game, which I wrote for A&E Networks based on their History Channel 
series, along with my clue writer Julie Marsh (Julie was not credited on 
the game itself, as I was featured, but I am compelled to include her 
for consideration due to her essential contributions).

I was attempting to bring the genres of television writing and videogame 
writing one step closer. I was given nearly free reign by the network 
and showrunners on how to proceed, and so decided to write my own 
adaptations of half the game's cases based on produced episodes of the 
TV series (with additional scenes that I envisioned) and the other half 
of the cases as original cases which I based on actual declassified 
U.S.A.F Project Blue Book files.

The Production Draft encompasses all 9 Cases of Season One of the game. 
Because this document is quite lengthy I have also attached "Case 105: 
The Aztec Recovery" (in which I introduce J. Robert Oppenheimer to the 
game's story) and "Case 107: Project Rainbow" (in which I 
introduce Albert Einstein to the game's story, in a story previously 
dramatized as the feature film /The Philadelphia Experiment/) as two 
smaller samples of the complete work.

Besides the script, the game is FREE TO PLAY as a mobile app available 
for both IOS and Android phones and tablets in the safe links listed 
below, and I invite you to play!

Project Blue Book: The Game on IOS 
<https://apps.apple.com/us/app/project-blue-book-the-game/id1445162277>

Project Blue Book: The Game on Android 
<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.threegates.projectbluebook&hl=en_US>

And for anyone who does not wish to actually play the game, here are 
two youtube videos posted by players that depict the game's opening 
tutorial, and the start of CASE 101, The Fuller Dogfight.

Project Blue Book Opening Cut Scene and Tutorial 
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UFhBUpUeqsE&t=5s>

Project Blue Book Case 101 Walkthrough 
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOhAgdjG7bY&t=23s>

And finally, here is the approved description from the app store:

Project Blue Book: The Game is the official, free-to-play, hidden object 
adventure game based on HISTORY’s hit drama series PROJECT BLUE BOOK, 
created by David O'Leary, and executive produced by Academy Award and 
Golden Globe® winner Robert Zemeckis. The series explores the 
historical, Top Secret investigations into UFOs conducted by the U.S. 
Air Force between 1952 and 1969.

In Project Blue Book: The Game, you will start off as a newly recruited 
agent in Project Blue Book during the 1950s, under the guidance of the 
show's lead investigators, Dr. J. Allen Hynek (played by Aidan Gillen 
from “Game Of Thrones”), and Captain Michael Quinn (played by Michael 
Malarkey from “The Vampire Diaries”), and begin to investigate real 
declassified UFO investigations to find the truth!

Hundreds of puzzles, witness interviews and hidden object scenes will 
challenge your observation and deduction tactics as you investigate 
alongside your favorite characters into many of the cases you loved from 
the series, uncover exclusive new content, and explore new cases that 
can only be found in the game! The game's story is written by 
bestselling science-fiction writer and award-winning game writer 
Steven-Elliot Altman, best known for similar social games like PEARL’S 
PERIL and ANCIENT ALIENS.

We're here to find the truth! So, come help us investigate flying 
saucers along with Dr. Hynek in the world's first Unidentified Flying 
(Hidden) Object Game!

Thank you for considering *Project Blue Book: The Game* for a Nebula 
Nomination in the best game writing category. Should you wish to 
nominate it, here is the SFWA link: https://www.sfwa.org/forum/ballots/ 
<https://www.sfwa.org/forum/ballots/>

Love and light to you and your family,
Steve

*Steven-Elliot Altman*
Chief Executive Officer

  Phone  +1 (323) 708-9005
  Fax       +1 (877) 581-8750
  Site Socialimpulse.com <http://Socialimpulse.com>

To: Pamela Melroy <pamela.a.melroy@gmail.com>
Subject: Oh my goodness!

Pam,

I hope this is still a good email address.

In looking back, I realize that it's been THREE YEARS since I last spoke 
to you!  I think perhaps I took the whole "Pam's busy, don't bother her" 
thinking a bit too far.

I hope you're doing well.

I'm in Las Vegas these days and hanging in there.

Recently I've come to the notion that we're going to need rotating 
centripetal-gravity producing stations to survive in space (of course, 
whether the moon's gravity would be sufficient remains to be explored.)  
This brought me back to the whole Gerard K O'Neill's Space Settlements 
publication (it was a NASA SP at one point).

I noticed that DARPA has just recently announced NOM4D which sounds like 
a good start on space manufacturing (it seems like something that might 
have your fingerprints on it).

I'm in the process of writing the President to suggest that we need a 
new great challenge for our nation and believe that the time is ripe to 
push fully into space... and staying there.

I was wondering if you had any thoughts on that or pointers to thoughts.

I'm also trying to build a near term science fiction story line based on 
this (sorta Space Cadet but for the 21st century).  I had an "aliens 
invade" dystopian idea set on the asteroid belt (called "Minor's War" 
because it's a YA about asteroid miners taking back Earth) but my heart 
is never really in dystopian/apocalyptic stories.

A proper rotating space station would also be a great place to learn how 
to properly create self-sustaining environmental systems.  Also, we 
really need to start to learn how to build stuff in space instead of 
simply boosting it pre-built from Earth.

Anyway, I hope you're well, challenged, and happy!

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

that have been curated.

Wouldn't it be nice if you could look at two courses side by side and 
see unbiased reviews from users on how good they really are?

Well, to solve this, I’m trying something new.

I created a course marketplace for self published authors:

 * Have a place where you can find many courses made by real authors
 and not just the few
 * Give you the ability to read legitimate reviews by users
 * Have the ability to compare courses side-by-side

In this course marketplace, my team scoured the internet, asked authors, 
and compiled a list of beloved courses on all types of subjects in 
self-publishing, such as book marketing, advertisement, writing certain 
fiction genres, etc.

We then went over their information and created special pages for each 
course like this:

On these course pages, you can now see:

 * Who this course is for
 * What you’ll gain from the course
 * The full course curriculum with total time in each video
 * Information about the course creator
 * Unfiltered reviews left by previous course takers

Now, you can compare different courses to each other and see how they 
stack up.

With this course marketplace, you’ll finally be able to compare apples 
to apples.

 Is there a course you have taken? Please leave a review!

One thing that will make this marketplace unique is that you can leave 
reviews on any course and thus read what previous course takers think.

But to do this, *we need your help*. Check out the courses listed and if 
you see one that you took, please leave a review.
