Write an email in my voice.
To: opinion@nytimes.com
Subject: Op-Ed: How I didn't become a racist

**

*How I didn’t become a racist*

*

By Todd McCaffrey, BSME, MFA, SFWA, New York Times Bestselling author

I think it’s important to understand America’s underlying inclination 
toward racism. It doesn’t just come from our parents. It comes from our 
community, our society, from the people we grow up with.

I am an alien, so I think my point of view may be helpful. When I say 
I’m an alien, I’m an alien in Ireland: where I lived for my high school 
and college years. I describe myself as “mid-Atlantic and sinking.”

My journey toward racism started in late elementary and early middle 
school, before I moved to Ireland.

I moved to Long Island, New York, in time to enter third grade. The 
school was small and the community tight-knit. There were only two black 
kids in the whole school — they were brothers, a year apart. Nice guys. 
The younger one had a small bit of iris detached in the white of his eye 
which amazed everyone who saw it.  I remember constantly asking to look 
at it — it was just so cool!

My parents were determined to raise broad-minded children and when the 
chance came, introduced us to people from all  over the world, including 
a Nigerian who stayed the weekend with us, arriving in the marvelously 
bright Nigerian native clothing.

Still, in school hallways, there were the whispers. That blacks would 
beat kids up, that you couldn’t trust them.

This whispering became more apparent in middle school and I think, had 
it not been for my relocation to Ireland, that background whispering 
would have lodged firmly in my mind.

But, barring that lingering underlayer of fear, I like to think that the 
full implant of racism didn’t take with me.  And I think that’s because 
of my time in Ireland… and two people in particular.

In Ireland my classmates said: “I hate all Yanks!” to which was hastily 
added, “But not you, I know you.”  Such statements are examples of 
prejudice and bigotry. It was my first experience of prejudice directed 
at me.

The two people who broke the back of racism for me were strangers.  One 
was a classmate, the other an actor.

We’ll take the second first.  He is Lenny Henry — now SirLenny Henry.  
He is a black comedian. Hearing a very English accent on a black man 
broke the mold that society had tried to impose on me about black people 
— that they all spoke the same.  That was a revelation to me, a “Wait, 
what?” moment. Not all blacks are the same.  My fourteen year-old 
thinking went like this: “So… this notion that blacks are a threat or 
menace… that’s a lie!”

My second revelation came with my classmate, Obudan Obesan. Obudan, for 
me, will always be the primal proof that skin color means 
absolutelynothing!  Also, he proved that James Joyce was a second-rate 
author. I can’t remember when we read Joyce’s The Dubliners.  I’m pretty 
sure it was after I’d first been exposed to Mr. Obesan’s writing.  The 
thing is, Obudan gotthe feel of the Irish, the Dublin Irish, down pat.  
He had it better than Joyce. Waayyybetter than Joyce. Nearly fifty years 
later, my opinion has not changed.

Between Obudan and Sir Lenny Henry, I threw out that notion that black 
people were inferior.

With the benefit of hindsight, I can see how American society has a 
built-in underlying prejudice against people of color.  It starts as the 
whispers in middle grade and high school corridors: “You can’t trust 
them.” “They’ll beat you up.” It’s something that we should be aware of, 
should recognize... and banish.

Because black culture has imbued our society with somuch. Even while we 
derided it, it gave us rock’n’roll, starting with Chuck Berry. The black 
culture is more vibrant and alive than the old, tired white culture. We 
can and should learn a lot from it.  The first step is to recognize 
that. The next step is to embrace this difference, to grasp it and learn 
from it. Our society will grow stronger when we do.

*

Write an email in my voice.
To: Lois McMaster Bujold <lbujold@myinfmail.com>
Subject: Millisor Rau

Hi Lois,

I hope you and yours are doing well in these wild times.

I'm writing because I have a book I started when a friend told me, "My 
sister was drying explosives in the over."

(No, the house did not burn down, surprisingly. The explosives were 
sparklers for a school science project.)

I figured that it was such a good starting premise that I just /had/ to 
write the novel.

Anyway, one of my tertiary characters decided that, as she was going to 
gene-engineer her own child, she would name him from her favorite 
"pre-space" science fiction series.  And so, currently Engisn Millisor 
Rau is serving on HMAS Sparkle (laundry ship for the Navy).  He also 
becomes the OCTO - Officer Candidate Training Officer - for one of my 
heroines, the girl who turned him down when she was a teenager (/Oh, 
damn, the one boy I've ever broke and he's my commanding officer!)/

Obviously, it's an homage on my part.  If it causes you grief, then I 
can change the name but I hope it meets with you approval.

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

Good morning all:)

 Expanding Universe 7. This short story anthology series has
 received great acclaim, found its own reader base, and helps
 authors snag new readers. 

 I apologize for the mass send, but I find that time is growing
 more precious. I have very little of it left. Bear with me. I'm
 looking for fifteen headliners and then will open it to about
 five newer folks to the genre.

 I've attached the Tom Edwards cover we'll be using for this set.
 The theme is Don't Run Afoul of the Cover. You could write a
 story about the planet below or the events that led up to the
 space battle, or the warriors themselves, or even a single scene
 within the ship. So many possibilities. 

 A short story of 5k-8k words.

 Complete story in ready-to-publish form (I've attached a Word
 template) due by August 15th.

 TEU7 publishes on Sep 13 for a three month run in KU.

 You'll get your exclusive ebook rights back before Christmas

 We'll publish the paperback in perpetuity (unless paperback
 exclusive rights change and then we'll unpublish it - we'll do
 right by the authors)

 There is no cost to participate and every contributing author
 will get an advance of $100. 

 All participating authors are asked to share the set to their
 Newsletter (twice during the run) and on social media channels.

 Let me know if you'd like to participate. This will be done with
 contracts, everything will be above board.

 Thank you,

 Craig

Write an email in my voice.
To: customerhelp@newscientist.com
Subject: Your marketing is really, really, really bad

I'm writing this to you in the hope that this will help.

Your recent "Pi Day" Ad was successful to the extent that I clicked on 
the newsletter and went to the first subscription page.

Faults with the first subscription page ("Step 1'):

- You didn't link your image to the hyperlink to your Step 2 page 
(https://subscribe.newscientist.com/default.aspx?prom=16450&pkgcode=T&term=3I),

just the "Subscribe" button.  You always want to make it easy for the 
customer to proceed to the next step.

On "Step 2" 
(https://subscribe.newscientist.com/default.aspx?prom=16450&pkgcode=T&term=3I)

Firstly, whatever you're using to switch between offer packages is 
clunky and slow (Javascript should enable you to generate a 
highlight/hover effect).

Secondly, your offers are "bad" and "worse."  Remember that your 
audience is mostly college educated, savvy people.

The first offer "Option 1" has the rate of $1.05 per week for 3 weeks 
(catchily reduced to $3.14 -- pi) with an automatic continuing rate of 
$49.99 per quarter. Sneakily below you say that this is a 85% savings.  
It is, but just for those 3 weeks. Not quite a "bait and switch" 
advertising tactic but damn close. I think less of you, your marketing 
department, and New Scientist in general for such sharp business 
practices.  Also, you fools, you're dealing with college educated people 
who tend to *think*. So you're insulting your potential subscribers' 
intelligence at the same time. Shame!

If you'd really wanted to woo me back, you'd have made the 3 issue "pi" 
deal which ended *without* automatic renewal at the usual (exhorbitant) 
rate.

"Option 2" -- $314.00 for 3 years with a "saving 70%" is too much.  I'm 
a prior subscriber to New Scientist but I stopped subscribing because I 
found the online version not as compelling as the print version (you 
didn't replicate formats, nor did you try), so asking me to take "a pig 
in a poke" -- to make a 3 year commitment to a product I'd previously 
declined -- is just too much.  If I had evidence that New Scientist was 
such a deal, maybe then but not right out the gate.

You make no other in-between offers that might give me a chance to 
determine whether New Scientist is now something I want in my media 
stream (which currently includes New Atlas, WIRED, The Economist, The 
London Times, The New York Times, and various others).

If you had some in between offers ("a third of a pi", "a slice of pi", 
etc.) that might have interested me.

In conclusion, you failed to get a new subscription and a large part of 
that is due to your poor marketing and arrogance.

Wishing you the best,

Todd McCaffrey

Kindle Vella graphic header with story image

 A new way to tell a story

Kindle Direct Publishing is introducing a new storytelling option: 
Kindle Vella. With Kindle Vella, you can self-publish serialized 
stories, one short episode at a time. Episodes can range from 600–5,000

Oh, ouch! Head injuries are tough to

.

I'm thrilled that you love the cover
 art! Our Brit wanted the minimalist cover and I think she was

 be taken lightly. Take it slow, easy, and don't strain yourself.

Hi, Todd,

So far so good...all three of us are vaccinated and we've moved
 Michael back to his apartment in Austin (boy, is HE happy!!)  
 We're still masking when we go to stores, offices, etc and doing
 as little of that as possible.  I'm still in recovery from the
 2017 and 2018 brain injuries, but it's coming along.  I've
 written one salable story and am working (too slowly) on
 revising another Vatta book.   (Injury one left me with the lack
 of judgment about buying a new horse when the old one died
 unexpectedly...that new horse bucked me off the first time I
 mounted her at home and dumped me on my head.  Also kicked
 Richard hard in the leg.  I never went to the hospital for a
 checkup after the first injury (DUH)  so the second one (which
 did involve an ambulance trip) was considered "minor" because I
 was only unconscious very briefly.  They didn't know about any
 of the previous head injuries (4?  5?) .  This one left me
 unable to read more than a few simple sentences at a time, or
 write anything but short nonfiction (posts on Twitter and FB) so
 I spent most of two years recovering the ability to read and
 write.

Anyway, this will explain that while I would love to read 
The
 Magpie's War
 & love the cover art,  I still cannot
 read fiction that fast, and I still have a problem reading from
 the screen, though I write on the computer now.   I would need
 it in paperback, and my reading for review-level understanding
 of what I'm reading (usually takes reading a book three times at
 least to remember characters, motivations, etc.)  is glacially
 slow--no luck being able to send a nice quote to your editor by
 any rational deadline.  I'm really sorry about that, because I
 miss being able to read something in two days and come up with
 something useful.  It may come back; improvement is still
 happening but not as fast as I'd like.  Also I need to spend the
 most time on my own monster...selfishly, but I really, really,
 REALLY need to get more books out.  

So it's up to you, whether to waste a paperback on me or not. 
 And now I must get back to my untitled,
 still-in-revision-because-first-draft-was-really-bad, project.

Blessings,

Elizabeth

Subject: A/C woes

Dear Mr Lee,

I would like to request someone to fix the A/C. Here is the situation. 
The A/C system is one condenser with two internal thermostats, one 
upstairs and one down stairs. There is a damper, which is movable flap 
inside the duct work that directs air flow downstair or upstairs 
depending on the settings of the thermostat.

At some point in time in the past one of the thermostats was 
disconnected and so the damper does not adjust airflow, since there is 
only one thermostat attached.

I would like to get the second thermostat reconnected and confirm the 
damper is working correctly to cool both floors as soon as possible.

As it is right now, the AC is running continuously. Even when the system 
is turned OFF, the fans still run. When the system is set to COOL, the 
thermostat setting downstairs has no effect -- and the system runs 
continuously, without regards to temperature (the temperature has been 
68 when the thermostat was set to 72), nothing short of turning the AC 
to OFF on the thermostat effects that (and, as I said, even then the 
fans continue to run). None of this can be good for the AC system.

At this very moment, my room temperature is 79.3 degrees which is 
intolerable.

I look forward to hearing from you immediately.

Sincerely,
Todd McCaffrey

Write an email in my voice.
To: David Weber <davidweber@davidweber.net>
Subject: Thank you!

Hi David,

Thank you for getting me a copy of "A Call to Insurrection!"

it was much enjoyed!

One niggle -- at the end of the last book, Calvingdell and Locatelli are 
involved in a coin toss over who gets Travis. I  do wish that had been 
explicitly resolved.

It's nice to see Travis and Gavin communicating.

The situation with Serisburg seemed to beg for a bit more preamble and I 
thought Chomps might have been a lot quicker on the up-take. I think I 
also would have liked to see more personalities involved in the 
ONI/Delphi clash.

Even though I've seen them both before, I got a bit muddled with 
Damocles and Diacritos -- both being D names. I would have loved a bit 
more of "the courier ship, Diacritos" to keep them clear.

I do certainly look forward to more!

Cheers,

Todd

Write an email in my voice.
To: Bill Fawcett <bill@billfawcett.com>
Subject: Model Art Contract?

Hi Bill,

I'm hoping to license a piece of art for inclusion in a book cover. I 
was wondering if you knew a model contract for that sort of stuff or had 
one of your old contracts lying around that I could use as a template.

In other news, I am now the proud owner of a Tesla Model 3.  I'm still 
getting used to a car you plug in at night and to the really awesome 
acceleration (compared to my sturdy old Prius which had to be /begged/ 
to pick up speed).

I was thrilled that one of my more "out there" shorts (written from a 
dream) has been picked up by Galaxy's Edge.

What are you and Jody doing with yourselves? My prediction is that 
COVID-19 is going to linger and our society may have to adjust to a more 
"at home" (like "home on the range") less contact society.  I would hate 
for that to come to pass but lately I've been thinking a lot about 
expansion into space (16 Psyche is potentially worth more than 70,000 
years of Gross World Product) and am tempting myself to write stories in 
that not-so-distant future.

I hope you're all well (you've got Dragon*Con coming up soon). I'm still 
getting used to you guys being down near Atlanta.

Cheers,

Tod

To: Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
Subject: How's it going?

HI Squeej,

I've been saying to myself for a couple of weeks now, "I should write 
Gigi and ask her how things are going with her."

So... How's it going?

Over here, we're hanging in. We're worried about the delta variant, 
particularly because Brit's doctor has told her specifically NOT to get 
the vaccine -- it might make things much worse for her.

As it is, Brit will be heading back to LA to see an eye doctor at UCLA 
because in the past several weeks she's noticed two very troubling 
things: her hearing has gotten worse and her eyesight has gotten worse.  
A good retinal doctor here in Vegas detected signs of thinning in the 
optic nerve.  Not good.  Brit took the news in stride.  She's hoping 
that it's Usher's Type 3 because then she'll have a diagnosis.  It also 
helps that the eye doctor in UCLA has seen her before, willingly calls 
*her* and is also the guy who originally determined the existence of 
Usher's Type 3. Anyway, we cross fingers.  In the meantime, Brit has got 
hearing aids and loves being able to hear things she didn't notice for 
the past five years -- like being able to hear her nails tapping on things.

I am busy writing a sequel to a novel I just completed.  The first 
novel, RAW SPACE, is out with alpha readers.  You know, nothing out of 
the ordinary, just a space opera where someone has planted zombie sex 
bugs on the Fleet's laundry ship ;)

I hope you're doing well.

Love,

Todd

Write an email in my voice.
To: Todd McCaffrey <todd427@gmail.com>
Subject: Fwd: How's it going?

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: Re: How's it going?
Date: Sun, 22 Aug 2021 06:03:07 +0100
From: Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
To: todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Ah, sweetie! It’s lovely of you to check in, and probably couldn’t come 
at a better time.
You asked, so I ain’t gonna hold back. Tune in your big brother 
listening ears cause your baby sister needs sound advice. I have to 
admit, I’m not doing too well. Wish I could fluff away, all light and 
breezy, and tell you ‘I’m grand’ but I’m not. I guess it’s a combination 
of things but, predominantly, living on my own, away from the area I’ve 
known for over 40 years, is incredibly hard and seems to magnify any 
other difficult issues I experience in my life as a single 60-something. 
It’s like I’m starting all over again, when I’m already starting over 
again since my marriage ended. The property market here is a mess, with 
houses selling far above asking price because there’s a scarcity of 
stock for sale, so I can’t afford to buy anything now and lay down new 
roots. The holding pattern I’m in is excruciating!

And I guess other aspects of my life, and the seemingly never-ending 
crises that are engulfing the earth, are all mixing together to fill my 
plate with a gloomy looking repast. I should stop reading the news.

Sleep is difficult; I’ve been wide awake for an hour and it’s not yet 
5am, so this day’s store of resilience is already fecked up. - I have to 
go to Owen’s girlfriend’s place today to help celebrate the “gender 
reveal” (slap me quick before I gag!) they have planned now that their 
gestating baby is 3 months along. It’ll be the first time I’ll be in the 
same air space as Geoff since we were in court getting our divorce 
decree; when I bawled my eyes out in front of everyone whilst giving 
testimony. Oy! Added to that, Owen has, frankly, been treating me like a 
piece of shit over the last few months so the strain is telling. I’ll be 
a big girl, though, go along to see what sex the baby will be and try to 
smile a lot.

About two weeks ago Geoff’s youngest sister, Edel, the main carer for my 
(ex?) mother-in-law, Joan, was in a terrible car crash while travelling 
to Cork for a weekend break with her boyfriend. She’s broken the bones 
in the top of her foot, and two vertebrae just above the tailbone. She 
literally broke her arse. Poor Mick, her boyfriend, is far worse off and 
will remain in hospital in Cork for at least another 6 weeks, undergoing 
another couple of surgeries on top of the 3 he’s already had. Fuck! What 
a nightmare, and no visitors allowed to see him. Poor guy.

And then a totally strange series of things have occurred recently with 
regard to my late sister-in-law’s husband, Noel. He’s a very successful 
businessman and a pub owner and has been trying to cope with the sudden 
death of his wife in June 2019, along with the grief their two (young) 
adult kids are experiencing, plus the lack of pub business due to Covid.

I’ve kept in loose touch with Noel ever since he asked me to write and 
deliver Maria’s eulogy. Over the last couple of years, through texts, 
he’s always suggested that we get together for a drink and catch up 
which I’ve always put down as pure politeness. Recently he suggested the 
same thing but in a phone call when he told me about Edel’s crash, which 
no one else in the Kennedy clan had informed me of.

Edel has always been close to Noel and she asked him to drive to Cork to 
be with her whilst she gave an official report to the Gardai regarding 
the crash. So here’s where it gets weird, Tig. Noel asked me to drive 
with him to Cork to collect Edel but suggested we go down the day before 
her release, have a nice meal, a few drinks and “a laugh”, and stay the 
night in an hotel before we retrieve Edel the following day. Whilst he 
was suggesting this plan I was uncommonly quiet on the other end of the 
phone and Noel said we would, of course, have separate rooms because he 
“wasn’t going to try and climb into bed with me”. The thought never 
crossed my mind! To be honest, I wasn’t sure what the fuck was going on 
but it’s been a very long time since I’ve been in the company of a kind 
man who wanted to hang out with me, so I agreed, thinking what harm 
could come of it.

At any rate, as it turned out, Edel didn’t have to have an interview 
with the Gardai in Cork and without discussing it with me, Noel changed 
his initial plan ‘to have a laugh’, and we simply drove to and from Cork 
on the same day to collect Edel. I reckon he possibly had a good think 
about what he’d proposed and decided against it. We had a pleasant time 
talking on the way down to Cork but I couldn’t forget the fact that I’m 
fairly certain he’d possibly made a pass at me. Or did he? I have no clue.

So my silly girl head can’t stop thinking about this, and Noel. In fact, 
it’s wrecking my head, and living alone doesn’t help; I already spend 
*way* too much time in my own head. I keep scolding myself to stop! but 
I’m lonely, and would like a man to like me again. I guess I’m just 
going to have to let time do it’s magical thing and allow it all to 
slowly fade away. Talk to me, Todd. Give me your take on this. Sorry 
this is so long but, hell! I’m long-winded.

Love,
Skin

To: Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
Subject: Updates and all

Hey you!

You have received at least TWENTY mental emails or more in the past while!

I figured I'd go electronic this time.

Let's see:

1. Got a book coming out in Beta, /RAW SPACE/.

2. Working on a Kickstarter campaign (my first) for the sequel, /The 
King's Ghosts, /which I'm actually still writing (I won't launch the 
Kickstarter until after I've got the alpha version done). I'm having a 
blast with it!
//

3. Loving my Tesla.

4. Worried sick about Brit. The HOPE is that she's only got Usher's Type 
3 which is, at least, not fatal.  Of course, you go blind and deaf but 
at least you still live. SIGH. It's also possible that she's got a 
mitochondria disorder (some of which ARE fatal <grrr>).

Her hearing went out about three weeks ago and everyone's been madly 
scrambling.  Eyes are not much better, peripheral vision is pretty much 
shot.

We play D&D at Zeke's once a week. We have three people who ZOOM in. 
Usually it's Sunday 1-5 pm (Pacific) but recently it's been Saturday 1-5 
to accommodate work/travel schedules.  You ARE invited, if you're 
interested.  It's not optimal timing for you (roughly 9 pm to 1 am) but 
the offer's open.

Brit also says you should come out to Vegas for a break.

Did I tell you that I got "Honorable Mention" for Illustrators of the 
Future for Q2 2021?  I've submitted for Q3 and Q4, we'll see what 
happens. It'd not only be cool but kind of a validation, too ($90,000 
for an MFA, after all).

I've also been putting up products on Etsy.com 
(https://www.etsy.com/shop/toddrics, if you're wanna take a goggle).  
Most of the times I'm taking covers and converting them for other 
porpoises (sic).

The twins are being photographed today by the local rag (The Las Vegas 
Journal-Review, formerly owned by the late arch-conservative Sheldon 
Adelson), having given a  superb interview last week.

We're looking at WonderCon in April (Anaheim CA) and San Diego 
Comic-Con.  Perhaps you'd like to tag along?

I'm also getting ready for 20BooksTo50K Vegas, which is an annual 
convention for Indie writers.  Good people.  I'm giving a presentation 
which I pared down from 90 slides to just 32 because I'm told I won't 
have time for more (couldn't quite hit the recommended 30).

If you'd like, you can join my Beta for /Raw Space/ 
(https://dl.bookfunnel.com/1vdyzug5rl). You'll be asked sign up for my 
newsletter before you can get the beta and I'll remind you (along with 
everyone else) to please submit a reivew on Amazon.com at the 
appropriate time.

I heard from Sonia Lyris who seems bummed that her books aren't doing 
well.  We're going to talk more next week.

I also spoke with the "other" Gigi Johnson and hopefully we'll get 
together, maybe do a podcast (I'm the one who doesn't get it together on 
these things).

Anyway, that's things in my neck of the woods.

I love you and hope things are going well for you!

-- Todd

Regarding all of Mum’s documents, I have them in storage now that I no longer have a large home to store them in. I’m renting a wee little cottage, and have been for the last 12 months. I’m renewing my cottage lease for another year as the property market in Ireland is insane and it simply isn’t a prudent time to buy - not unless I want to live in Bally-go-backwards, miles and miles from friends and the amenities I use and am familiar with.

So. I have been paying €50 per month to store all the trust documents since last year. (I also pay for my own possessions to be stored but they are in two completely different containers and at a much higher storage rate. I managed to get a ‘grandfather’ rate for Mum’s things because she’d used that company for more than a decade.) Unless I win the lottery or there’s an overnight crash in the property market, I foresee continuing to store the documents for another year. 

I would like the trust to repay me for last year’s storage costs and also for the next year’s costs. I see no reason why the trust cannot afford this. Sorry if I sound pushy, it’s not intended, but let’s be fair, Jay, as I’ve been more than fair over the years.

As for you being paid for storing documents related to the trust,
 I think it's  a no-brainer and you have my vote.

Cheers,

Todd

Message: Good day: Beacon College (https://www.BeaconCollege.edu) is a 
nonprofit liberal arts school in Leesburg, Florida and America’s first 
accredited baccalaureate institution dedicated to educating students 
primarily with learning disabilities, ADHD, dyslexia, and other learning 
differences. The college launched a television show in August 2020 
called “A World of Difference.” In each episode, “A World of Difference” 
examines neurodiversity issues related to learning disabilities 
experienced from birth to adult years, using compelling storytelling, 
conversations with experts, viewer Q&As and interviews with successful 
individuals with learning differences of their own. In just eight 
months’ time, the program has garnered a raft of honors including from 
the Education Digital Marketing Awards and PR News’ CSR Diversity Awards 
and has expanded (and continues to grow) its reach to 11 channels in 
eight states through regional, public, educational and governmental 
(PEG) stations. “A World of Difference” is available throughout the 
United States via public access TV channels, and is available globally 
via the college’s Facebook and YouTube channels. You can watch our most 
recent episode here: https://youtu.be/zmO9ef5iKxw One of the segments of 
which we’re most proud is “Difference Makers.” The feature salutes 
someone famous and/or successful who has a learning difference, or 
someone is a successful advocate for individuals with learning 
disabilities. We are interested in presenting The Winner Twins with our 
“Difference Maker” Award (https://beaconcollege.egnyte.com/dl/EsGCgOGdCL 
for their exceptional contributions to literature and their 
determination to succeed while living with learning differences, and the 
founding of Motivate2Learn. “A World of Difference” airs on WACX Orlando 
Superchannel 55 (which is available in 1 million Florida cable homes). 
It’s produced by a multiple-Telly Award and Emmy-nominated production 
company, NG Production Films. The show also is more widely available on 
our Facebook Watch and YouTube channels and the show’s website, 
https://www.AWODTV.org. More exciting, later this month we sign a 
contract to put the program into the PBS pipeline, airing soon on WUCF 
Orlando. Previous “Difference Makers” have included: • Dr. Temple 
Grandin • Retired U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin (the architect of the Americans 
with Disabilities Act) • Stanley Cup champion hockey player Brent Sopel 
• Shark Tank’s Daymond John You can view “Difference Maker” segments 
here: https://awodtv.org/category/difference-maker/ All that would be 
required of the Winner twins is for them to sit for an interview, either 
virtually or in-person (their choice), so we can create the segment. I 
look forward to hearing from you. Grace to you and peace, Darryl E. 
Owens Host/Creator Beacon College’s “A World of Difference” 352-638-9789 
phone 407-335-1455 mobile https://www.AWODTV.org

To: Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
Subject: Catching up

Hi Squeej,

I see from the Irish Times that you're all being inundated.  I hope it's 
not too bad. Curiously enough, it's raining here in Vegas.

We've survived Channukah although I still have more gifts to give (so 
we'll get them out nearly to Xmas).

Dex tells me that he's taking Russian 102 next semester and a bunch of 
other stuff.

I binge watched "I am not okay with this" which, it turns out, Dex had 
recommended but I'd forgotten.

20BooksTo50k Vegas was a lot of fun, the first time I've been out for a bit.

I've slowed down a bit on my Canaris Rift series, had to stop and 
re-read everything and make notes so that I knew where I was in terms of 
equipment and all.

I also binge watched the 3rd season of the new Lost In Space which I 
quite enjoyed.  I've been following Hawkeye on Disney. In addition, I 
discovered "A Boy Called Christmas" which is now among my favorite 
all-time Xmas stories.

I hope you're doing well.

Love,

Todd

Write an email in my voice.
To: Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Catching up

"A Boy Called Christmas" is on Netflix. I just recently watched it again.

Good on you with the job.  It's nice to get out.

I do most of my writing at Starbucks. It's nice to look up and see 
people while I'm working.

Glad to hear that Owen is happy.

I've been submitting artwork to Illustrators of the Future (even though 
I'm a Writer judge, I'm allowed) and have received "Honorable Mentions" 
twice now. I'd rather like winning outright but I'll work on it.

I'm glad that you added your voice on the Hungarian translator. I quite 
agree that Mum would get a kick out of the whole thing and would be 
actively PUSHING to get it done.

I have a fan wondering if there'll be any more Tower & Hive books and 
another wondering if there'll be more Doona books.

At 20BooksTo50k I chatted with Kevin Ikenberry, another writer and, it 
turns out a retired LTC from the Army.  He's teaching the guys at 
Spaceforce. We were talking about writing a series set out on the 
Asteroid Belt as I believe that's the next great frontier and we should 
get into it (as a species) so writing about it might help the movement, 
as it were.

Any collaborations like that will wait until I get the six (hopefully no 
more) books in the Canaris Rift series done.  I just recently did a new 
cover which I decided I'd use for the fourth book, /Pirate Queen/, which 
is right now at 18,000+ words.

The Twins got a really cool write-up in the local newspaper, The Las 
Vegas Review-Journal 
<https://www.reviewjournal.com/rj-magazine/amazing-stories-of-the-unbelievable-sci-fi-sisters-2474997/>.  
You can read it by following the link.

We're thinking that our next major convention will be WonderCon in April 
2022 (Anaheim Convention Center, just across the street from Disney).  
Maybe you should consider coming, see what working a booth is like, get 
out and see the weirdness that is a comic-con (and then do Disney to 
recover <g>).  I'm sure that tons of fans would love to meet you, and 
you'd be surprised at how rewarding it is to interact with them.

After WonderCon, it's Writers of the Future the very next weekend! (whoosh!)

Love you!

-- Todd

 "Craft Day" provides the opportunity for you to spend one day (the day 
prior to the main seminar) focusing on the craft of writing in intensive 
sessions led by industry professionals and bestselling authors. You'll 
choose one three-hour session for the morning, and another for the

Workshops to be determined.
Craft Day AM (choose 1 AM session if you purchase Craft Day) AM: 
Jonathan Maberry, Bestselling Pacing 
 Novels can be short or long –and in some genres very long—but they 
should all move along at a brisk yet compelling pace. NY Times 
bestseller Jonathan Maberry, author of over forty novels in multiple 
genres, is your tour guide for a journey through the art and science of 
PACING. Topics covered include Creating the Right Novel Structure, 
Timing, Red Herrings, Foreshadowing, Plot Complexity, Overlapping 
Storylines, The Importance of Supporting Characters, Pacing in Single 
Character POV and Ensemble, Shifting POV, Parsing Info Instead of 
Dumping, Varying Forms of Dialogue, Building a Story Chronology and more!
Craft Day PM (choose onePM session if you purchase Craft Day) PM: Hugh 
Howey, Full Sensory Writing 
 In this workshop you will learn that there are more than five primary 
senses, and you will master techniques to tap into them all. You will 
also learn how to place yourself inside your scenes and craft the little 
details that convince your readers that what you are describing is real, 
not fiction. After this session, you will be well on your way to writing 
action scenes that feel cinematic, dialog that is authentic, and 
characters who leap off the page with extra dimension.

Post-SSWS 2022 Survey

Thank you for attending our 12th Superstars Writing Seminars!

It was our biggest and best event to date, thanks in part to your 
feedback on past conferences.

We want SSWS 2023 to be even better. To help us make this happen, please 
fill out our brief survey. Your experiences, opinions, and comments 
really matter! We read every single one and take each suggestion into 
consideration, so don’t miss the opportunity to help shape next year's 
event.

Please go to this LINK (https://forms.gle/f4ZiQu2BFccjfkW77 
<https://api.webconnex.com/v1/postmaster/track/click/7215e7e9bf3b401d8e18e4226aee9590/85b4933b8f4111ec9d740243a424b527?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2Ff4ZiQu2BFccjfkW77>) 
and fill out the survey *before Friday, March 4th*.

If you choose to include your email address, you will be entered in a 
drawing for A FREE CRAFT DAY at SSWS 2023.

(/Please note that if you include your email address, only the survey 
administrator will be aware of your identity—no identifying information 
will be included in the data analyses or shared with the planning 
committee/)

In addition to the survey, we are *always *open to feedback and would 
love to hear from you.

Thank you again for being a part of Superstars 2022! Making cherished 
connections with our growing Tribe is always a favorite part of this

To: Angel Adams <angelinasvista@gmail.com>
Subject: Audio Work

Hi Angel!

So... there are two projects:

1. Cloud Conqueror (Twin Soul Series #2)

2. The Jupiter Game (that's me)

The idea is:

1. Convert from manuscript to "screenplay" (really, radio play-ish) format.

2. Create audio suitable for ACX.

I've already done a full audiobook with ELLAY (and it's making money!!) 
which is why I think this might be a good idea.

I'm willing to pay for the conversion, the output to be in FinalDraft 12 
format (.fdx) but, of course, if I think the price is too high, I'll do 
it myself.

For the audio stuff, the going rate is $250 PFH (per finished hour) 
which, quite simply, I can't afford (which is why I was the sole voice 
for ELLAY). However, perhaps a royalty share?

You can get a 30-day trial of FinalDraft here <https://finaldraft.com/>. 
After that, if things work out, I might include the cost of you getting 
it in our deal.

Attached are the 1 page original and 1 page script format to give you an 
idea of what I want.  The way I handle it, I create SIDES so that I can 
read each voice separately, then the "general description" is what I 
read as the narrator. (You wouldn't want to go from the "screenplay" 
that I produce to the screen without editing, that's for sure! <grin>).

Anyway, take a look, let me know if you (and y'all) might be interested!

Love,

Todd

To: Monique Bucheger <monique.bucheger@gmail.com>
Subject: Re: Trouble Blows West

Hi Monique,

Thank you for your patience, I read Trouble Blows West.

It did not work for me.  Permit me to emphasize, it did not work for *me.*
*
*
Here's why the book didn't work for me:

Ginny's character just didn't seem real to me.  It became less so as the 
book progressed. Her mounting anger and vengeance didn't have any 
rational background to support them and her unwillingness to listen to 
reason or learn finally killed any sympathy I might have had for her.

I also questioned the setting -- was this in the 1970s? 80s? 90s? 
Earlier? Later?

Ginny's love for her mare didn't work for me. I grew up with horse mad 
girls, and Ginny didn't fit.  It seemed to me that her horse was at 
about the same level in her affections as a rusted hand-me-down bicycle.

I began to notice the number of chapters.  There's an *awful* lot of them.

I also wasn't sure about the farm -- was it a cattle farm? Dairy? Crop? 
Mixed use?  That question nagged at me and helped pull me out of the book.

Cheers,
Todd McCaffrey
